Glow-worm â€“ 0.1

Ward is the second work in the Parahumans series, and reading Worm first is strongly recommended.Â  A lot of this wonâ€™t make sense otherwise and if you do find yourself a fan of the universe, the spoilers in Ward will affect the reading of the other work.

Ward is not recommended for young or sensitive readers.

The Glow-worm chapters were a teaser event leading up to Worm 2.Â  They arenâ€™t required reading but offer flavor and additional angles by which to view certain characters.Â  They take the form of forum posts, chat conversations and emails.

Theyâ€™re best described as a kind of a post-epilogue, pseudo-prologue bridge between the series.Â  Those who read them on the Worm site shouldnâ€™t feel the need to read them again â€“ theyâ€™re included here for convenienceâ€™s sake, with a few readability improvements.

If youâ€™re not interested or find this hard to read, click here to jump to chapter 1.

â™¦ Â Topic: Â Weâ€™re Back Online
In: Â Boards â–º Parahumans Online
Hope_In_Pithos (Admin)
Posted on August 15th, Y1:

To call the efforts of everyone involved heroic would be grossly understating things. This IT project required the efforts of seventy eight PHO staff members, employees of Stateside Online, former officials of the US government, former members of the United States space program, members of international space programs, the Guild (Masamune in particular), and numerous independent experts and volunteers. At a time when weâ€™re all stretched thin and there is an incredible amount of work still to be done, seven hundred and eight individuals devoted spare time and valuable resources to get us and six other partners online.

Things will be clunky and frustrating. Â For most, with congestion being what it is, things will be slow enough that people can get a cup of coffee and come back to find the page hasnâ€™t fully loaded.Â  Weâ€™ve stripped away a bit of the polish and the gloss: the header images, badge graphics and the ability to include video or images are gone for now, to keep things simple and easy. Â We will be moderating very carefully to ensure nobody disrupts anyoneâ€™s ability to access the site. Â It will be painful.Â  Help each other, be patient, and contribute the best you can.

In so many ways, things will be frustrating, slow, and painful.Â  Care, helpfulness, patience, and contribution will make literal worlds of difference.Â  In so many ways.

But weâ€™re back.Â  Stay tuned for bigger, better things.Â  Bear with us as we sort through it all.

@ Dgators â€“ Generally, you want to be careful because you wonâ€™t get any updates to OS360 or other PC OSes, no patches to your phone.Â  There is no tech support and there is little recourse for anyone hit with malware. Plausibly thereâ€™s a lot of desperate people out there who see that the defenses are down and weâ€™re in early days.Â  Itâ€™s probably easier for someone to come up with new means of attack than it is for anyone to roll out a proper patch.Â  Presumably if they wanted to infect systems or get access they would want to do it now when it would probably let them get access to things that follow.

â™¦ Â Topic:Â  [Headline] Refugees Barred Access
In:Â  Boards â–º World News â–º Main
Boo-chan
Posted on August 17th, Y1:

[Transcribed from print]Â  Conrad James Freed and his family could tell a harrowing tale of their trip across Earth Betâ€™s America.Â  They have finally reached the Northeastern Bet-Gimel portal, hearing rumor of wait times, only to be told there is a possibility they may not be allowed in at all.

They had been driving, hitchhiking and hiking for four months.

â€œThey arenâ€™t giving us answers,â€ he told Bulletin News on Saturday.

Their family had been trying to subsist on their rural property in Wisconsin when the weather took a turn for the worse.Â  Though it was June, Conrad says he saw snow falling on the fields where he had planted the first crop of the season.

Two days later, there would be a knock at his door.Â  Authorities had flown over and saw the lights of his house.Â  They warned him the snowfall and the groundwater was contaminated.Â  It would be the last straw, as the unseasonably cold weather had cut into the already thin initial harvest.

Conrad says the authorities wanted him and his family to leave right away.Â  â€œThey didnâ€™t give us a chance to pack.Â  One of the men even grabbed my daughter.Â  He bruised her wrist, he held her so hard.Â  I promised I would cooperate if he would only give us five minutes.Â  I was in shock.â€

He and his wife decided to make the harrowing trip to the nearest portal without the assistance of authorities, a decision he says he made on the spur of the moment, after the manhandling of his daughter and the manner in which he was forced from his home.Â  â€œI came to regret that decision.â€

Conradâ€™s story is far from unique.Â  Evacuation is still underway even two years and two months after Gold Morning.Â  Where things took a turn for the worse for Conrad and his family, and where an undisclosed change in policy may affect uncountable refugees from Earth Bet, is that the border agents have apparently ceased processing refugees.Â 

Tensions are rising and as the number of people in the refugee settlement slowly climbs and resources are stretched thinner, people are speaking out.Â  Conrad says, â€œWe know there is more than enough space on the other side.Â  We see people coming and going but they wonâ€™t let us through or even meet us to answer our questions.Â  Weâ€™re willing to settle outside of the city.Â  I know agriculture and I know they desperately need farmers.Â  Even if they give us a minimum of supplies and tools, it has to be better than this.â€

Bulletin News reached out to authorities and received no response.

â€“Thoughts?Â  Anyone know what was up?

â™¦ Topic: Info & Update
In: Boards â–º Teams â–º Reach (Private)
Moonsong
Posted on August 18th, Y1:

PHO is back on and they are letting the chats run. Thatâ€™s where we usually meet, but Iâ€™ve been warned itâ€™s choppy and slow. Iâ€™ll be there.

This took me three hours to just get started with. Itâ€™s hard.

It is with the heaviest of hearts that I inform you that Coiffure did pass. When Gold Morning arrived, we suspected something might have happened, given the reports. She was killed in one of the initial strikes on the East coast. She was a friend, a teammate, and she was a true hero. She elevated others around her to be better people by the standards she lived by.

Coiffure is survived by only her father. Her mother was one of my favorite adults. She was kind, she was cool, and she was a genuinely good mom to Coiffure. When we went back to school in the fall, she gave us really cool back to school supplies. It remains in my memory as one of the most randomly nice things a relative stranger has done for me.

Youâ€™ll also remember her siblings Arthur and Cal, though you might not remember their names. When the family came by, Arthur would be the one curled up in the big chair near the front desk, with one of his game things. Cal would be watching over his big brotherâ€™s shoulder. I always thought it was hilarious how uninterested they were in capes.

We can expect they all died instantaneously. Iâ€™ve talked to Coiffureâ€™s father. I would suggest that if you happen to run into him, leave him be. He doesnâ€™t want reminders.

Furcate decided to fight on that monumental day and that says so much when not everyone was brave enough to do that. Furcate was wild and tortured and beautiful. They were a handful and yet they rewarded us with ten positive things for every negative we had to overcome. Iâ€™d like to think they got something out of putting up with us in much the same way.

I want what I say here to be honest. I did not get along with Furcate the vast majority of the time. Furcate did not get along with me. I still respected them immensely. They said one word for every thousand the rest of us said and yet they could convey so much in their actions. I keep saying those things, using math like â€˜ten times overâ€™, but itâ€™s so very Furcate. They overflowed, they swelled. The cup runneth over. I look back and Iâ€™m dazed by how much of a place they found in my heart and my thoughts.

It might be crass to say, but I donâ€™t know if anyoneâ€™s going to have words for them. Scritch and Scratch were the closest thing we had to a nemesis. They had their scummy moments. They also kept to the rules. They were killed during one of the lulls in the fighting, by a group I wonâ€™t name.

The fates of Tribute, Boundless, Capricorn and Steamwheel are yet unknown. I hope you guys are okay.

Iâ€™m alive, obviously. Figurehead is alive but you all should know his issues with being controlled. The events really shook him. Heâ€™s retired in large part, heâ€™ll be doing something capey, but heâ€™s said he isnâ€™t coming on PHO. He asked me to wish you all the best.

â™¦ Topic: Amnesty & The Devil We Know
In: Boards â–º News â–º Events â–º Gimel.US
E.S.Reaver
Posted on August 19th, Y1:

Iâ€™ve seen a few articles and wanted to compile them. Thereâ€™s a narrative here, if you donâ€™t grasp it then bear with me an Iâ€™ll sum up my thoughts at the end.

Article: Strange Reversals: Villain to Hero & Forum Thread
The number of heroes is rising. Multiple known villains have shucked off the black capes for white ones. Which is a good thing, right?

Article: No Witnesses Remain & Forum Thread
The article identifies three villains who we know about in heroic groups â€“ two with the Wardens and one with Shelter. They committed crimes, we have some limited information or scraps of wiki articles, but the witnesses of those past crimes are either dead or yet to establish themselves. We established standards for amnesty, but sometimes those standards canâ€™t be met. The ex-villains find places on the team with nobody to naysay.

Article: Two Black Raincoats & Forum Thread
Letâ€™s get to the examples. Four youths tried to get superpowers by working off of the â€˜triggerâ€™ theory of power gain, and became a newsworthy case in 2004. The event got out of hand, one boy and one girl took charge and preyed on the two younger members of the group, torturing them over the course of a weekend. Nobody gained powers, the search for the missing children led to the two older children being identified as they went into town on the Monday to get food and buy power tools, including a circular saw. They revealed the location of their victims; one of whom apparently lost fingers as the wire that was used to attach them to the toilet tank was too tight. Unnamed Boy was sent to juvie. Unnamed Girl was sent to psychiatric care. Both gained powers while in care, both were released in or around 2009. Reuniting, now with powers, they killed three people, wearing black raincoats to keep the blood off, and were not caught. They have been spotted in several locations at the Rochester span, wearing the black raincoats.

â€œFor the time being, the amnesty applies,â€ Chief Armstrong stated to the media. â€œWe know where they are and weâ€™re keeping tabs.â€

Good enough?

Article: â€œRendedâ€, â€œTorn Upâ€, â€œDismemberedâ€ & Forum Thread
Written after Miss Militia and Vista, heroines under the Wardens, were seen on several occasions in the company of Hellhound, also known as Bitch or Rachel Lindt. Raises questions about the moral compromise the amnesty has wrought and the longstanding allegations that the Protectorate team in Brockton Bay was cooperating with the local villains. Once the relationship is established and weâ€™re reminded of the past examples, the article devotes the latter half to reminding us of some of Rachel Lindtâ€™s deeds when she was working with a group of warlords to seize Brockton Bay.

â€œEvery day, I wake up and I try to move my leg. The wind gets knocked out of me when it doesnâ€™t move like it should. If Iâ€™m active at all during the day, then the pain hits me in the evening.â€

Article: Fallen: What You Need To Know & Forum Thread
The Fallen operate as a cult and theyâ€™re one of the largest cape groups around. The article doesnâ€™t talk about it directly, but the forum thread has some great posts on the subject (see page 3 and 12). Their recruitment numbers are swelling and I (and others!) think itâ€™s the amnesty thatâ€™s letting them get away with it. Thereâ€™s a lot of talk of Lachlan Hund [article linked] elsewhere and there might be a court case revolving around what others are saying was a powers-assisted abduction. Totally Fallen M.O. for years prior, family says Lachlan never showed any pro-Fallen sentiment before this.

Article: No Cost & Forum Thread
Same article author as â€˜No Witnesses Remainâ€™. Following up on several villains who didnâ€™t turn hero, the author finds two villains, both anonymous, who claim they received accommodations, at a time when many were still living in the tent cities. They got ahead of the â€˜lineâ€™, they got basic apartments and utilities paid for, and they contribute nothing except the fact that they arenâ€™t (as far as we know) committing crimes these days. Itâ€™s like weâ€™ve caved to extortion.

We need to have a dead serious conversation about the amnesty. Justice shouldnâ€™t fall by the wayside. Absolutely horrific individuals get their second chances but they get them at the expense of the safety and peace of mind of others. They get things easier.

We heard the arguments why at the start. We had other things to think about and deal with. Heroes had other things. We thought. We dealt. The heroes handled the biggest needs. That was then.

Donâ€™t get me wrong. Iâ€™m not buying into the anti-cape sentiment you see here and there.

But Iâ€™m anti-these-capes. Iâ€™m anti-this.

â–º Mangled_Wings
Replied on August 19th, Y1:
There are three kinds of villain. There are villains at rest that donâ€™t do anything unless bothered and they may be easy to bother. Donâ€™t bother them unless youâ€™re sure youâ€™re stronger than them. If you donâ€™t have powers you arenâ€™t stronger than them.

There are villains in motion. They want something or theyâ€™re going somewhere. Donâ€™t get in their way unless youâ€™re a lot stronger than them. Catch them from the flanks or from behind if youâ€™re strong and clever enough.

These two kinds of villain donâ€™t budge. Iâ€™ve known a lot of them. I know how they operate. It takes a lot to move the ones at rest and it takes a lot to change the course of the ones in motion. You canâ€™t do either. Donâ€™t try.

The third kind is the kind worth paying attention to and theyâ€™re the ones that are changing or that can change. Objects in motion stay in motion and objects at rest stay at rest and the times and situations to watch out for are when they change states.

The people bitching here donâ€™t know enough and donâ€™t have the power to handle any of that. Get stronger. Get smarter. Leave it to the people who know stuff to tell each group apart and to know when to handle things.

â™¦ Topic: [JRPNA] Use of Cluster Powers, Serial Powers, Matched Powers, and Nth-generation Powers to identify â€˜Hinge Pointsâ€™ in Power Expression â€“ 1998
In: Boards â–º Parahuman Science
Azavael (PRT Science)
Posted on : June 4th, 2002

[Article] Studies into Parahuman abilities presently catalogue studied powers into three major databases: the PRT database in the US, the Cambridge Parahuman Studies facility, and the EUJP International Listing. The lists are formed by way of interview and laboratory studies with each institution using universally standardized forms in addition to supplementary material. Each of these three institutions have stated an express or strongly-implied desire to understand and predict expressions of power and tie these expressions to the inciting incidents. However, a longstanding problem in this process is that powers expressed, inciting incidents, and contextual factors can be dramatically different across individual cases. While some common themes can be drawn out, derived results are traditionally very big-picture. It is only recently that databases have begun to include sufficient numbers of special-case triggers that allow more focused study of how powers are expressed. We identified cluster powers, serial powers, matched powers, and Nth-generation powers as the special cases to focus on in more focused examination of how power instances can be mapped and we posit a â€˜Hinge Pointâ€™ illustration of power expression and theory.

[Definitions] â€¢ Cluster powers are defined as powers wherein multiple inciting incidents occur either simultaneously or within a minute of one another. Such parahumans will have a collection of smaller powers related to the others. â€¢ Serial powers are defined as cases where an individual or multiple individuals in longstanding proximity to a parahuman will develop powersâ€¦

[Click to read full article]

(5 of 280 replies match search criteria)

â–º WMD377 (PRT Science Admin)
Replied on August 20th, Y1:
Keep in mind that serial and Nth-Generation (2nd gen, 3rd gen) powers are now the same thing.

âŠ™

â™¦ Topic: Multi-Trigger Case Studies â€“ Parahumans 303 Class Notes (Spinky) â€“ September 15th 2009
In: Boards â–º Parahuman Science â–ºNon-Articles
Rightsector
Posted on : September 17th, 2009

From Wednesdays with Prof Spinky. Posted with permission. Cleaned up where I could

Overview: What are clusters?
Other names are mosaic p. expression, grabbag, multi
Effect on resulting power
Why important & Importance to study.
Case studies
Greater effects, things to keep in mind

Pt. 1: What are clusters?
2-6 people trigger at same time or very close together. Each gets a suite of powers. Person A gets Person A primary power and fragment of B, C, D, E, F.
Person B gets Person B primary power and fragment A, C, D, etc.

Pt 2: Effect on resulting power
Term secondary expressions. Weaker or subtle power. Can be conditional.
Primary powers may be weaker than if they had triggered alone?
Powers inspired by others but not identical. Relation may be tertiary.
Example given firebreath -> fire something or something breath
Prof stresses this is very basic example
Term for staying element is hinge (old) or dominant (current). Relates to 1998 article.

Pt 3: Why important & importance to study
Suggests powers arenâ€™t 100% predetermined. Certain elements are highlighted or made dominant.
We can extrapolate from studies like this & serial triggers to work out key elements of existing triggers. What changes & why = what factors are important in standalone non-special trigger?

Case Studies: two cases & how we look at them
Two case studies. Interview, self-reporting, examination

Case Study #1: Sunder Bros
Take note for future week: matched powers. We come back to this.
Brother #1 â€“ Destruction caused to objects ripples out indefinitely, stopping at clear demarcations (images included in lecture notes). Weapon extension without limit (except convenience)
Brother #2 â€“ Weapon sweep extension â€“ some range extension â€“ wider arcs, shockwaves left/right of swing. Stomp to destroy ground in immediate area.

Class pauses, prof asks & responds to input re: dominant factors in each power.

Cute girl in red top finally comes up with answer that satisfies Spinky. Destruction & weapon attack augmentation dominant/staying/hinge factors. Question of range vs. breadth between brothers. Not very lopsided in power difference b/w primary & secondary power. Spinkyâ€™s stress on not.

We get some slides of brotherâ€™s recreation of trigger circumstance. Distance from threat. Prof Spinky highlights personality traits brothers used on forms they filled out. All as reasoning for different power expressions.

Case Study #2: Fowl & Fair (foreign capes, names that follow are badly translated)
Oxfair â€“ Physical augmentation; size, strength, speed, agility (<- primary), deafening roar, transfer harm from falls/some impacts to nearby others, pain resistance/faster healing
Ramfair â€“ Emotion affecting chant, size increase, some ability to heal very recent damage of others listening to chant/that touching, gather strength/concentrate -> giant leaps
Foulcock (yes, the class laughed) â€“ Flight with build-up of speed over time, speed is transferred to touched others, interrupting flight to deliver high-impact blows. Increased agility, deafening shriek, fast recovery of smaller wounds (scratches yes, no recovery of larger wounds).
Foulpig â€“ Personal biokinesis, swell into flesh bubble with fast recovery/personal mutations if not â€˜poppedâ€™ in time. Some strength & size increase, but slower while grown. Ability to â€˜rollâ€™ with incoming impacts (mover expression? Turns into boulder). Guttural noise (flatulence? Burps?) to interrupt thought processes â€“ turn off othersâ€™ brains momentarily.

Discussion of dynamic. Fair & foul on opposite sides post-trigger. Only fair provided answers & allowed power testing, rest has to be inferred. Handouts.

Some discussion of trigger event (see slides for images), some discussion of resulting â€˜packageâ€™. Powers for each individual distinct but play off each other in semi-complementary way. Reflective of personality? Or â€˜guiding handâ€™ principle?

Pt. 4: Greater effects & things to keep in mind â€“ things touched on in homework reading:
Kill / Kiss â€“ more on this in parahuman psychology class in a few weeks
Personality Bleed â€“ personality traits bleed over from 1 individual to other? Messy
Higher incidences of paranoia, confrontation, aggression, PTSD. Less bounce back?
Higher rate of death post-trigger. Kill / kiss again. Graph
Prof Spinky stresses emotional states may play into the above. Triggers that are sufficient to draw in multiple individuals are worse than average. Canâ€™t jump 2 conclusions. Correlation =/= causation.

â™¦ Topic: [EUJPR] Relationship Entanglement in Cluster-Triggers â€“ 2005
In: Boards â–º Parahuman Science
Jr_Max
Posted on : February 18th, 2005

[Translation] Colloquially known as the kill/kiss dynamic, in cluster-triggers, there is a very high tendency toward passionate relationships, either hostility or partnership. Clusters have a 40% chance of one member murdering another, rising to a 50% chance when including attempted murder, 25% chance of a partnership forming, and a 10% incidence of partnership and murder coinciding. The term partnership is used for romantic pairings in instances where sexuality and gender allow, and close friendship or formed teams with members in other cases. In some (10% of) cases of close partnerships forming, the romantic pairing occurred despite oneâ€™s typical sexuality. The relationship entanglement study looks at existing cases and clusters to investigate why.

The most dramatic case in recent memory is the StÃ¡j, also known as the Stable, or the Foul and the Fair. The Good Ox was turned into a grisly display [â€¦]

[Click to read full article]

â™¦ Topic: Public Incident Report [Aug 16]
In: Boards â–º Teams â–º Gunslingers
Lucky Luke (Hero)
Posted on : August 16th, Y1

[â€¦] We were ultimately unable to stop them, as they had two capes we had no information or records on. The first of the capes may have been a thinker, likely the same that shot down our flier. We were unable to glean much more from them, other than the fact they wore fur in the midst of a heatwave.

The second individual seems to be a grab-bag cape. She was a woman with a fanged mask covering her lower face, and a form-fitting dress with a slit up the side of one leg. She displayed a mover power [fourth term] with the ability to run on walls. She produced an emotion-affecting [third term] roar, which broke the ranks of one of the cooperating teams, and had metal claws [second term] which looked to be of tinker make. These claws may have been what enabled her to tear [First term not met, but within allowance] down doors and other barricades with the ease she did. We have the beginnings of a work-up going online shortly.

The attack on the store opening was a failure on our side. We were late to the scene due to geography and we lacked full knowledge of our adversaries. It is our belief that with PHO in working order and more collaborative tools and measure being put in place every day, that we will succeed next time where we failed this once. We are working with authorities to keep an eye out for the stolen merchandise.[â€¦]

Subject: Your Nilles University Application
August 21st, Y1
Dear Applicant (Point_Me_@_The_Sky@mail)

We regret to inform you that your application for graduate study in our department was turned down. We look at each application and applicant as a whole and decisions are based on a composite of information including your previous academic performance, referrals, relevant professional activities, proposed research statements, and test scores.

Due to a high volume of applicants, this message has been partially automated. Your application was received by paper and email and discussed by me and one other faculty member. We responded by email as per your preference. We would like to stress, for your particular application:
â€¢ That we would very much like you to apply again in future years.
â€¢ That we would encourage you to use the same email address, as we can easily tie it back to this application.
â€¢ We felt your academics were very strong.
â€¢ We felt your extracurriculars were exceptional.
â€¢ We felt your references were exceptional.
â€¢ In a time when records are often lacking and references may be hard to identify or contact, your application stood above and beyond in how complete and thorough it was.

Nilles is one of three Universities serving an estimated population of fifty million on Earth Gimel and its associated territories, and it is the sole post-secondary institution offering graduate studies. Over one and a half million bright and eager minds have applied to Nilles in avid hope of starting or resuming their educations, and regretfully, with our current facilities, we cannot accept more than twenty thousand.

Although these circumstances mean we must regretfully send you an unfavorable response, we appreciate your application. We wish you the best in your future endeavors and look forward to hearing from you next year.

Yours truly,
Dr. Marilyn Ginbar
Graduate Advisor

â™¦ Topic: Multiversal Travel Warnings
In: Boards â–º Gimel.US
Khain (Guild Staff)
Posted on August 22nd, Y1:

The Guild is presently established in three facilities outside of the city in Gimel.US, supporting authorities and serving as bodyguards and representatives for the onetime denizens of Earth Bet, as new areas are surveyed and contact with new cultures is made.

The process is exciting and interesting, and we report back as much as we are able, but it does have its hazards. After two recent incidents, we have decided to reach out to those we are familiar with, who are familiar with us. This forum is one of many places weâ€™ll be striving to communicate needs and necessities.

Humans are explorers by nature. Our best count right now, excepting areas we cannot fully access, is that portals, devices, and tears between realities are currently allowing access to forty-seven Earths. Six of those Earths have been blocked off due to implicit threats or are fundamentally inaccessible. Two more have been closed off at the request of their denizens. Earth Aleph, which most Earth Bet residents are or were familiar with, has been blocked off as well.

Speak with authorities before making any trips to territories unknown. We donâ€™t and canâ€™t mount effective rescue operations if someone leaves and fails to return, but we have some ability to do so if and when authorities know where youâ€™ve gone and youâ€™ve stuck to the established route. People got lost or stranded in the wilderness on Earth in 2012, with all that worldâ€™s satellites. It can and will happen in new universes.

Do not travel to inhabited worlds. Absolutely do not make first contact. The first of the two incidents noted above was one where a family traveled across Earth Chamesh and happened across a settlement we were currently talking to. Much confusion and concern was had and we are still recovering.

The second is to please stick to charted territories. Exploring the uncharted is exciting, but if you arenâ€™t equipped, you can come to harm, even if the world is uninhabited. One ex-Bet government (which shall remain unnamed) sent one expedition to Earth Achat. The Europe of that world was home to an invasive species, which grew as a tubular mold in dark, shadowed spaces, particularly in forest. Eating food exposed to the spores these molds created causes stomach cramps that progress to reflexive vomiting over the course of two to five days. The vomiting then lasts another two to five days, causing death by dehydration for any who donâ€™t receive care.

Be aware:
â€¢ Earth Gimel has been partially explored and checked by thinkers. There are no guarantees. Except for some rare indigenous colonies, it is unsettled. Gimel has five major points of settlement, with civilization finding its foothold around these points. The City, as of yet unnamed, is the primary US point of settlement and one of the primary waypoints. The City is a megalopolis with a commonly cited population of fifty million. A rough map (one month out of date) here.
â€¢ Earth Mem has been partially settled by others from Bet. We are currently trying to establish some kind of communication and link.
For novice explorers and those looking to settle new territories, we would encourage Gimel and Mem as largely safe options.

â€¢ Earth Bet has been deemed uninhabitable. Contrary to popular belief, radiation is not a major concern. However, many industrial sites were either destroyed or have weathered the last two years of neglect poorly, with chemicals leeching into groundwater and settling in valleys. Terrible numbers of deceased humans and other living species have led to other health concerns, particularly in previously heavily settled areas that received heavy damage. There will always be those who attempt to hold onto what we have lost, and many persist in trying to maintain some existence on Bet. However, new incidents arise on what seems to be a weekly or twice-weekly basis, with one in three having to do with powers, the powered, untended tinker technology, masters, and lingering threats. We may one day return to Bet, as some groups have fervently expressed a desire to do, but we have a great deal of work to do before this is possible. It may not happen in our generation or our childrenâ€™s generation. Be aware that if you choose to return to Bet (and most authorities agree you have the fundamental right to do so) you may have to re-apply for entry and you will very likely be putting your well being in peril.

Speak with authorities before traveling to any other worlds. More information on multiversal threats.

More information to be disclosed about outside threats and cultures as we have it.

(Showing Page 108 of 270)

â–º Slayer of Isaac
Replied on August 22nd, Y1:
@ Venturain â€“ that was our mindset. My family tried it.
We had the bad fortune of settling at one corner settlement. Two points removed. We got off to an okay start. Shelter up, food out, basic needs covered. Regular trips to the city to supply up and cover more advanced needs.

Winter of Year Zero caught us off guard. We thought we were ahead of what we needed but staying warm gets hard and getting warm means chopping wood, which means physical effort, which means needing more food.

I was handling most trips into the city. I was worn out and got real sick. My brother handled one trip, asked for help, came back with capes.

They helped, yeah. Then they took over. It was bad. You can find my photo diary on my user page.

My brother went out and asked for help again. The second time around, the capes were willing to fix the problem and leave. Most of us moved back to the city. Bitter feelings.

Subject: PHO Technical Assistance
August 24th, Y1
After discussion among the moderation team, we have agreed to allow the name change. As we discussed in the tech help chat, our primary concern in these situations is an abuse of the system or a lack of accountability. This being said, your account is in good standing and youâ€™ve agreed to a probationary status.

Your in-account email, curated lists, private messages, badges, and accesses will remain intact, as will your forum accountâ€™s connection to your wiki contributions.

Let us know if there is anything else we can help you with.
Graham at PHO

Subject: Re: PHO Technical Assistance
August 24th, Y1
Thank you so much! I am having another problem. Iâ€™ve been getting caught up on my PMs/DMs/Emails and there is a lot of abusive content. All of the recent messages are very hostile or vulgar. It seems to have started before I even signed back on. I donâ€™t know why. Iâ€™m so sorry to raise problems when Iâ€™m probationary.

Subject: Re: Re: PHO Technical Assistance
August 24th, Y1
Graham here. I looked at the incident log and found one major incident that another site admin handled. An article came out here. Two groups online identified the people in that article and shared out their screen names and other information. We took action when people used PHO resources (direct messages, email) to harass one of the individuals in the article. We took action and removed them, but they may be returning with the use of new accounts and expanding the number of people targeted.

If you could report any or all of those involved, it would help us a great deal. For solutions, I can think of three options: you can continue to report so we can continue to take action (as these are not the people we want on PHO) and we can hope this quiets down, you can move to a new account and start fresh, or you can agree to give PHO staff access to your private messages so we can take action. This would involve us reading anything private in the conversations, and it would mean anyone messaging you was notified that PHO staff can read your things. We would limit this to only recent and new senders, so your friends and pre-existnig conversation partners would stay private. As a bonus the notification could help stem the influx.
-Graham with PHO

August 24th, Y1

â™¦ Topic: [Article] Weld to Warden
In: Boards â–º News â–º Events â–ºGimel.US
Ball-Chan
Posted on August 23rd Y1:

[Article Text, Editorial]His list of credentials starts off good. A two year tenure as a member of the Boston Wards with no offenses or misconduct reported to the media. He was the third monstrous cape to feature as an actor on a television show, the first to make a second appearance on TV, and the first monstrous cape with an onscreen kiss. He was the subject of a viral online image, released with various humorous captions, and it was a combination of this and arguably his small-network television appearances that gave him his popularity. He rode this success to a position as the first monstrous cape to be the team leader of the Wards. Ambitious fellow, isnâ€™t he?

Weldâ€™s popularity and time in the spotlight made him a figure of interest when, following undisclosed events in Brockton Bay, he turned from the established heroes and brought the vast majority of the monstrous capes in the Protectorate and Wards with him. Speculation flew as to why, and Weld was cagey when asked. No comment, the teenager said.

Weldâ€™s team was dubbed â€˜The Irregularsâ€™ in a play on the term for unconventional military squadrons and on the team being wholly made up of monstrous capes. At this stage, it was still possible to praise Weld for his efforts. He reached out to monstrous parahumans both American and international, and he kept his team together while carrying out deeds for the camera. Maintaining a group of such size isnâ€™t an easy task when its numbers are swelling like his groupâ€™s did. He wasnâ€™t too open about his methods or his teamâ€™s motivations.

Things take an ugly turn from here. When Chevalier announced that the PRT was mending its ways and that the person at the heart of the organizationâ€™s corruption had been defeated, Weldâ€™s irregular team of monstrous capes kept away and kept silent. Heroes called for unity, the Suits answered that call, sending many members to America to serve, following a schism of their own.

Even the defeat of Behemoth or the appearance of the new Endbringers didnâ€™t serve to bring Weld back into the fold. If anything, Weld seemed to note that his teamâ€™s numbers were dropping. He and the monstrous capes serving under him stopped making as many public appearances. We donâ€™t know what he started doing at this time, but his team was still recruiting. No comment, Weld said.

Itâ€™s telling, too, that Weldâ€™s appearance changed. He decorated himself with horns and scales. To those with an eye for the symbolic, Weld was a monstrous cape who was embracing the monster and turning his back on the cape side of things.

More time passed, and more silence followed. No comment, he said, on the rare occasions when he appeared in front of the cameras. No comment.

On that Thursday, June 20th, 2013, Scion took our world from us. He took almost everything from us. Based on our limited accounts of what happened, Weld was there for the initial foray, an organized series of attacks mounted from an oil rig. He was not there after, leading a substantial portion of his team to other venues. Thereâ€™s no indication of what he was doing, but we do know he wasnâ€™t there for the skirmishes on other worlds, against other major organized groups of parahumans. We do know he wasnâ€™t there for the follow-up confrontation on the beachhead.

Many will argue it was a chaotic time. No reports are wholly accurate, the world was ending, and the number of parahumans fighting was no doubt mind-boggling. Why make a point of this in particular?

To start with, today was the day Weld returned to Gimel after some time elsewhere. Weâ€™ve been told he was doing a combination of work in Earth Bet and spending some time touring other worlds in the company of the mass-murderer codenamed â€˜Garotteâ€™ and a pair of unnamed capes the two were friendly with. He was extended an offer to join the Wardens as a leader of one of the groupâ€™s cells, and he accepted.

People are applauding, it seems. Weld led a rather formidable team of monstrous capes away from the field of battle, at that critical point in our recent history. He came back practically alone, his team gone. Heâ€™s tight-lipped as to why.

His Wards team didnâ€™t do very well either, for the record. We havenâ€™t heard the full story from him there either. He claimed that he didnâ€™t want to disparage his former employer, and that they were still on positive terms.

Does he deserve the position?
Is he trustworthy?
Is he even that good of a cape or a leader?

Iâ€™ll remind you of two of his favorite words, while you mull over those questions.

â€œNo comment.â€

but i think we have the most powers at our disposal. thatâ€™s important.

and i think weâ€™re best equipped to have the answers when others come asking. i think thatâ€™s the most important thing by far. they are going to ask and we are going to want to have answers to offer them

i think we need people to start telling instead of hinting. information is the most valuable resource at all.

Casey_F08
Posted on August 23rd Y1:

I would like to thank you all for reading this. I was invited to post here by Quasi after I posted in some other places. Quasi has been talking to me and resurring me.

I remember hearing about the monster heroes and I never payed much attention to them. Now I think I am one.

My name is Casey Forks and I would be starting high school this fall if things hadnâ€™t gone bad. My mom hasnâ€™t been well for a long time and my brother has the same condition so we decided to stick it out and whether things. we had a shelter and we had some food. my dad and I went to stores and raided them for more foods that would last and we stocked up.

The shelter didnâ€™t work out. we all got headaches and dad said the air filters werenâ€™t sufficent. we went upstairs into the house and sealed all the gaps and dad tried to fix up the filters. long story short that didnâ€™t work out either. I should have tried to get somewhere safe but I stayed. I shouldnâ€™t have stayed.

I didnâ€™t think enough about monster capes or about those with powers but now I am both. Maybe I am not Casey anymore. I am frozen like the dead people who have lying on the ground for the years since the world ended, like a mummy without bandages. Mold grows on me and grows around me and it covers everything I can see and think about. I am a god of death and decay and I am an open fridge door with mold growing inside it and spilling out. with every passing day and hour and minute I am less like casesy and more a god of gross fridge stuff. my world of mold gets bigger every moment

I grew mold on my dads body and I could make him move. I grew mold on his brain and I got him to think and with his thinking I finally got the generator and the router and the phones working. It helped that I grew mold on the pieces and parts.

Now I am making my sister type because I cannot move any part of me a milimeter and I am asking heroes for help. Iâ€™m internet famous and there are articles written about my situation so that gives me some hope

But more importantly I am trying not to lose my mind. Quasi is helping me with that and he said you would all help by sharing your stories.

I am so scared that the heroes wonâ€™t save me but I am just as scared theyâ€™ll save me but they wonâ€™t be able to fix me. I am scared that I wonâ€™t be able to move. I am scared I wonâ€™t be able to hug a pretty girl or lie next to her in bed. I never cared about the rude stuff that much I thought that the cuddling would be the nicest part. I want to see the world through eyes that arenâ€™t moldy and to take a deep breath and scream or even laugh. I want to play soccer again with all my friends there and I want my parents to be there and be proud.

Tell me Iâ€™ll be ok.

(Showing Page 3 of 3)

â–º Casey_F08

â–ºEngel
Replied on August 23rd, Y1
Be strong brother. With powers all things are possible. Through trauma and struggle we find ourselves so much stronger. It takes time to adjust and it takes time and effort to find the right keys to the right locks. With help (and you have so much help!) Clocks can be turned back and flesh can be reshaped. We killed a god and the worst is behind us. Slowly but surely we will put the pieces back together. If I did not believe this 100% then I would not be here to write this message to you. Be strong.

FlippinMad: Yeah
FlippinMad: Thats kind of the plan. I want to anyway but the school turned me down.

Point_Me_@_The_Sky: Anything else?

FlippinMad: When do I get to put this behind me? When do I get forgiven or get to forgive myself?

Point_Me_@_The_Sky: Youâ€™re asking me? Never.
Point_Me_@_The_Sky: I donâ€™t believe in forgive & forget. Not for the things Iâ€™ve done. not for what others have done to people I care about. Not for whatâ€™s been done to me.
Point_Me_@_The_Sky: The moment we forget is the moment we allow those wrongs to be done again.
Point_Me_@_The_Sky: Forgiveness is the easy way out. Less to carry.

FlippinMad: That doesnâ€™t seem fair

Point_Me_@_The_Sky: Villains outnumbered the heroes. Now heroes outnumber villains. Allegedly. People lost everything and they didnâ€™t deserve to. Some people get powers and some donâ€™t. Things are the furthest thing from fair.
Point_Me_@_The_Sky: Maybe itâ€™s not fair that sheâ€™s gone and youâ€™re here.
Point_Me_@_The_Sky: Maybe you will get the answer about what happened and youâ€™ll feel better and thatâ€™ll be unfair because you shouldnâ€™t.
Point_Me_@_The_Sky: Maybe the opposite is true and no good answer will come out and sheâ€™ll be forgotten without tombstone or anything else.
Point_Me_@_The_Sky: I expect weâ€™ll get the answer and itâ€™ll be an unhappy compromise between the two

FlippinMad: It doesnâ€™t seem fair to yourself I mean

Point_Me_@_The_Sky: Iâ€™ll handle me. You handle you. You focus on making sure no girl you teach gets spat on, short girl from the photoshoot.
Point_Me_@_The_Sky: Itâ€™s easy enough to keep something moving once itâ€™s already moving, but getting it going in the first place is hard. Thatâ€™s the thing about second chances and fresh starts. Itâ€™s a (re)start. You gotta get things moving all over again, the second time around.
Point_Me_@_The_Sky: Letâ€™s try to make sure things are moving in the right direction. Alright? Deal?

FlippinMad: Alright.
FlippinMad: Not quite the response I expected

Point_Me_@_The_Sky: I had the impression itâ€™s the response you were asking for

FlippinMad: You might be right.
FlippinMad: Thanks

FlippinMad has left the conversation

Daybreak â€“ 1.1

Ward is the second work in the Parahumans series, and reading Worm first is strongly recommended.Â  A lot of this wonâ€™t make sense otherwise and if you do find yourself a fan of the universe, the spoilers in Ward will affect the reading of the other work.

Ward is not recommended for young or sensitive readers.

âŠ™

It was a second chance for humanity as a whole, and theyâ€™d gone and screwed it up from the start by coloring the city gold, of all colors.

The skyline was a half-and-half mix of skyscrapers and buildings in progress. Â The latter were skeletons of tall buildings in the process of being filled in and put together, and hazard signs, tarps, the materials that made up the countless cranes and the painted letters on steel girders were all in bright yellows. Â The completed skyscrapers were paneled with mirrored or reflective glass that were tinted in that same hue. Â All put together, the light that bounced off of the city and reached skyward gave the clouds linings that were gold, not silver.

It was such a fucking shame that it had to be the case, intentional or not.

My phone was buzzing with texts. Â I pulled it from my skirt pocket and looked while I walked.

Parental Unit 1:
BBQ tonight with everyone
My house
Can you come?

I glanced around to make sure I wasnâ€™t going to walk into anyone, then stepped off the sidewalk, into a gap between two display windows that bowed out and forward. Â In front of me, an assortment of people walked.Â  People in business clothes walked briskly, while some elderly people meandered.Â  A whole herd of kids were hurrying off to school.

I typed out my reply.

Me:
Thatâ€™s short notice

Parental Unit 1:
Michael is swinging by
There has been talk of everyone getting together.
It seemed worth trying to arrange
If you canâ€™t come thatâ€™s ok I understand

Me:
If I didnâ€™t come, would be because of work. New semester & lots to do. Might come very late

Parental Unit 1:
Spur of moment thing that is almost pulled together
Only missing you
Not to guilt you ha ha

Ha ha. Â She never liked using shorthand like â€˜lolâ€™.

No. Â No guilt at all, mom.

Parental Unit 1:
Come if you can
Will save you dessert just in case

My typed reply was interrupted by a crash. Â The stride of every person on the sidewalk in front of me and every person on the other side of the street was interrupted, as they stopped, heads turning.

I put the phone away, the message half finished. Â The impact had been at the nearest intersection, where a smaller road cut through one of the downtown areas.Â  I had to push through the bystanders closest to the scene to get there, and I could hear the victimâ€™s wail of distress before I was halfway through.

A car accident. Â There were no injuries, and I couldnâ€™t see blood. Â Nothing suggested that anyone had died. Â Not that anyone would have guessed by the sounds the man was making.

A teenager stood outside her car, the front corner and passenger-side mirror trashed. Â Sheâ€™d hit one of the pillars that lined the street.

An older man was doubled over, but he was on the far side of the pillar, not a location that suggested he could have been hit. Â He was elderly, with gray hair that still had color in it. Â Two people had already drawn close to him, supporting him while he knelt, rocking slightly in place. Â The sound he made was the heartbroken, strained sound that people made when they couldnâ€™t even draw in a full breath.

Such shitty, shitty bad luck, that heâ€™d been here when the collision happened.

â€˜Pillarâ€™ was the wrong word, but the right word felt wrong.Â  â€˜Monumentâ€™ implied something huge, but it was barely taller than I was, maybe three feet across at the base, tapering to two feet across at the top. Â Plaques were recessed into three of the four faces â€“ the fourth had come free and fallen after the collision. Â Each plaque bore an etching of a face, a name, a date of birth, a date of death, a message.

I looked down the length of the one-lane road. Â There were as many pillars as there were trees, and there were a lot of trees, enough that the sunlight that peeked past them was dappled. Â  This pillar was one of what had to be over a thousand that had been set throughout the city by now, punctuating quaint streets and surrounding parks. Â Places that were nice.

They were part of an initiative by an independent cape, a hero turned rogue, helping out.

There could easily be a thousand more of these pillars before the year was over, that number repeated every year thereafter, and if that work continued for another fifty or a hundred years, there wouldnâ€™t be a pillar for one percent of the people weâ€™d lost. Â Not even if â€˜weâ€™ were just the people who hailed from the northeastern U.S..

The girl whoâ€™d been driving the car had a thousand-yard stare as she faced down the small crowd. Â She looked like sheâ€™d just hit a real person and reality was sinking in.

The wailing stopped.Â  People were consoling the old man, some shooting hard looks at the girl who didnâ€™t seem to be registering much of anything.

â€œHey,â€ I called out.

She didnâ€™t seem to register that I was talking to her, as she stared at the lower portion of the pillar that had crumbled, stone chunks broken away, cracks webbing across the surface.

â€œAre you okay?â€ I asked her.

She nodded, said, â€œIâ€™m so sorry.â€

The old man looked up at her.

People in the crowd were staring, apparently angry on the old manâ€™s behalf.Â  One hapless teenager and thirty or forty very upset people.

â€œListen,â€ I told her.Â  â€œStay close by, okay? Â Iâ€™m sure someone in the crowd there is calling for help-â€

Someone in the crowd raised a hand to get my attention. Â They had a phone to their ear.

â€œ-Theyâ€™re calling for help. Â Theyâ€™ll be here shortly. Â Donâ€™t go anywhere, you can explain what happened, alright?â€

That seemed to get through to her. Â She nodded again, retreating to her car, apparently to sit in the front seat. Â Good. Â That was handled.

Until she stopped at the door, turned around, and addressed the old man and the crowd, â€œIâ€™m really goddamn sorry I broke your thing.â€

The grieving man rose to his feet, stepping forward at the same time. Â He pulled away from the supporting hands of the people around him, his face contorting.

I stepped in his way, my arm out. Â He pushed forward, and I caught him in a half-hug with one arm, stopping him.Â  He reached out and tried to push me aside, and I caught his arm.

He was a guy, but he was an elderly guy. Â It wasnâ€™t much of a contest.Â  The moment he met resistance, he sagged, and I did what I could to keep him from outright collapsing as he slowly sank to his knees again, sobbing openly.

I took the opportunity to turn him a fraction so he wouldnâ€™t be looking at the girl or the pillar as he knelt there.

In the background, that girl seemed to flounder in shock, useless, not sure what to do with herself in the face of this moment of violent grief. Â Â She looked at me, but I didnâ€™t want to say anything that might agitate the man I was dealing with. Â She looked to the crowd, and she saw only angry stares.

I wasnâ€™t sure what sheâ€™d seen, if it was a motion from someone, a particular emotion on a particular face, but she found the reason to get moving again, getting into the car, slamming the door behind her. Â The man I was holding jumped at the sound.

The man stopped resisting altogether.Â  It had been a fast enough change in attitude that I had to wonder at what he would have done if I hadnâ€™t intervened. Â Shouted in her face? Â Grabbed her? Â Would he have lashed out and struck the girl? Â If he wouldâ€™ve gone so far as to use violence, would it have been relentless, requiring people to pull him off, or would he have stopped the moment he was interrupted?

I gradually relaxed my hold on him.

The crowd, too, seemed to realize that the situation had mostly de-escalated. Â The girl was in her car, the old man wasnâ€™t an apparent danger to himself or others so long as I was here. Â That was enough for the assembled group to start breaking up.

I stepped back, hands partially raised in case he started forward again, and to enable me to act if he seemed like he might fall. Â I couldnâ€™t just say the pillar would get fixed, or that things would be okay. Â The old man hadnâ€™t shed tears for the pillar.

I didnâ€™t want to say â€˜sorryâ€™, and echo the kid in the car.

I almost asked if there was anyone I could call. Â I stopped myself when I realized the answer could be no.

â€œHow about we get away from here?â€ I asked, keeping my voice soft.Â  â€œWe can go grab a coffee or tea, and you and I can talk.â€

The man looked at me, as if just now realizing there was a person right next to him.

â€œItâ€™s got to be better than violence,â€ I said.

â€œI donâ€™t â€“ Iâ€™m not violent,â€ he said, sounding very small.

The heads of the crowd turned in reaction to something outside my field of view, and the old manâ€™s head turned as well.

Behind me, it seemed. Â A man in costume. Â It was a good outfit, too, more in the dollars that had been put into it than in terms of looks, but that was personal opinion. Â Partial discs of metal seemed to intersect his body, forming a look where he looked like a blender caught mid-whirl, axe blades and metal rings jutting from his breastplate, armguards, leg armor, and even his face, with blades running along one brow and cheekbone to frame one eye.

There were heavier blades at his hands and feet, such that it looked like he shouldnâ€™t be able to walk or even stand without difficulty. Â As it was, he had one end of his long-handled axe resting on the ground, the length of it bowing beneath his weight as he perched on it, one arm outstretched to one side, hand gripping the head. Â He was crouching on the thing while it rested at a diagonal, in a way that looked like heâ€™d wipe out if the end of the weapon lost traction on the roadtop.

Fuck me. Â Not what we needed right now.

The old man started to stand.Â  I helped him.

â€œCan I do anything to help?â€ he asked.

â€œI donâ€™t think so,â€ I said.Â  â€œMinor accident, weâ€™re just waiting for cops to come and assess things, take numbers.â€

I was barely done speaking when someone in the crowd said, â€œWe donâ€™t need you.â€

I watched him glance over the small crowd, looking for the person who had spoken. Â He kept looking out for the speaker as he told us, â€œThereâ€™s some police on their way. Â With all the reconstruction and the lower priority, theyâ€™re trying to get through the traffic right now.â€

â€œThatâ€™s good to know,â€ I said.Â  â€œThank you.â€

He nodded. Â He looked deeply disturbed by the one comment heâ€™d heard. Â I caught a glimpse of the emblem on his sleeve. Â A badge, not a personal symbol or icon, but part of the team he belonged to. Â Advance Guard. Â They were a team with an agenda to push. Â The world had ended, and they were pushing hard for a better and different tomorrow.

I could respect that.

I could also cringe inwardly at the fact that our superhero here was implicitly sporting a â€˜move forwardâ€™ ideology when that was the last thing this old man probably wanted to hear with a freshly reopened emotional wound.Â  Time and place.Â  Unfortunately, because of the team emblem the cape had on his breast- a stylized figure holding a shield shaped like a greater-than symbol, the guy represented that ideology every time, in every place.

He walked over to the car, still watching the crowd, and he exchanged a few words with the girl in the driverâ€™s seat.Â  I was glad for that, at least.Â  I had my hands full with the old guy and nobody else was stepping up to do it.

The cape stepped away from the car, looked at me and the old man.Â  â€œHeâ€™s okay?â€

â€œThe pillar.Â  Itâ€™s for his-â€ I started, looking at the plate on the pillar for a clue.

â€œSon. Â My son,â€ the man said.

â€œMy condolences,â€ the hero said.

The man tensed.Â  They were words that made it worse, not better, somehow.

â€œGo,â€ someone in the crowd said. Â A different person than the last.Â  â€œWeâ€™re fine.â€

The people that had been splintering away were holding position now. Â I could see the hostility.Â  The summer heat was holding out through the start of September, making things just a little more uncomfortable, tempers a little shorter.

â€œYeah,â€ the hero said, more to himself.

It put me in mind of a scene from the history books and the grainy old news footage of an event from the mid-80s. Â Back in the day, when the superheroes could be counted on the fingers of both hands, there had been a riot over a sports match. Â The anger and chaos had outweighed the respect the rioters had for the hero that had stepped in. Â Someone had struck out with a blunt object and hit the hero.Â  Heâ€™d died before he reached the hospital.Â  Weâ€™d called him the second cape after Scion, but he might well have been the first, after all.

Did I think that would happen here? Â No. Â Too small a group, the emotions were different, there wasnâ€™t enough chaos.

Still, the general setpieces were here. Â The barely restrained emotion. Â The lack of care. Â The ill-timed intervention of the man in costume. Â The lack of respect in particular was in play. Â For Vikare, it had been because so many people hadnâ€™t truly believed the powers were real, and he had apparently held back to avoid scaring people.

For this cape from Advance Guard, it was the opposite. Â Heâ€™d gone all out, weâ€™d gone all out. Â Capes still hadnâ€™t been able to stop the world from ending.

We were back at the beginning in so many ways.

â€œYeah,â€ the hero said again. Â He seemed to wrestle with what he was going to say next before deciding on, â€œIâ€™m going to go.â€

I wanted there to be people in the crowd who spoke up. Â I wanted there to be other things besides this sentiment of hostility and rejection. Â For this guy and for all the rest of us. Â Were there any people who wanted to say something positive?

Nobody. Â Or if there was anyone, they were afraid to speak out against the herd. Â I didnâ€™t want to leave it like this.

â€œNice response time,â€ I said.

He turned my way and raised an eyebrow.

â€œYou showed up quick. Â It was impressive.â€

He nodded, studying me as if trying to find the catch.Â  â€œItâ€™s what I do.â€

I wanted to say something more, but I didnâ€™t want to push my luck. Â It would have been nice if heâ€™d been less dismissive when I was throwing him a bone.

â€œTake care,â€ he said.Â  â€œCops are on their way. Â Iâ€™ll go let them know whatâ€™s up.â€

â€œThanks,â€ I said.Â  â€œYou take care too.â€

He stepped down from the pole of his battleaxe and set foot on the road.Â  Pavement splashed as if heâ€™d stepped in a puddle. Â More splashed and rippled as he moved his axe in a circle around him.

When he took a step and moved, it was faster than I could track. Â I could see the splash that followed behind, a cresting wave that quickly settled, leaving only a faint wavy pattern in the road as it dissipated.

Iâ€™d spoken against the herd. Â I tried not to pay too much attention to them or give them any excuse to push back against me, instead turning my attention to the old man.

â€œIâ€™m offering tea or coffee, my treat. Â We can talk it out, or talk about something else entirely,â€ I told him.Â  â€œAs soon as the police are done.â€

He still looked like he was carrying that fresh pain, in expression and posture. Â He flinched some as he looked at his sonâ€™s memorial pillar. Â He gave the girl in the car a hard look, then seemed to let the anger out, sagging.

She was in the driverâ€™s seat, both hands and forehead on the wheel.

â€œNo,â€ he said.Â  â€œYouâ€™ll have some place to be. Â I shouldnâ€™t keep you more than I have. Â Iâ€™ll be fine.â€

â€œWork,â€ I said.Â  â€œThey wouldnâ€™t fire me, especially if I explained. Â Iâ€™d get in trouble, maybe, but I wouldnâ€™t mind much. Â Job isâ€¦ a seven out of ten fit.â€

â€œSeventy percent is a lot better than some are getting,â€ the man said.Â  â€œKeep that job. Â Iâ€™ll manage now.â€

I glanced at the girl in the car. Â She had barely moved.

â€œYouâ€™ll leave her alone?â€ I asked.

â€œSheâ€™s a kid who made a stupid mistake,â€ I said, in case he was trying to come to a decision.Â  â€œYou donâ€™t have to forgive her, but you canâ€™t go and hurt her or anything.â€

â€œI wouldnâ€™t haveâ€¦â€ he said, and he didnâ€™t finish the sentence. Â Because he might have, or because he didnâ€™t know what he wouldnâ€™t have done.

â€œYeah,â€ I said.Â  â€œThatâ€™s good.â€

â€œGo. Â Work. Â Donâ€™t let me keep you,â€ he said.Â  â€œIâ€™ll be straight with the police there.â€

â€œIâ€™ll stick around for the cops and then duck out.â€

The police cars had appeared at the edge of the block, but with traffic on the narrow road slowed by the girlâ€™s car, theyâ€™d stopped there. Â The cars couldnâ€™t progress, but the police were getting out.

One officer went to talk to the girl, another to the old man. Â I waited around a minute, then gave a statement and my info.

As in most things having to do with law or bureaucracy, it took longer than it should have, for a relatively simple process. Â I hurried to the high school once they were done with me, and I arrived rather late.

High school.

We still werenâ€™t at the point where we had nice lawns and yards. Â This schoolyard was no exception. Â We had grass and fields, yes, but it was coarse and the ground beneath wasnâ€™t usually landscaped. Â The area was large with large trees left untouched in the corners, chain link fence separating the field from the roads on two sides, the grade school formed the third boundary to the west, and the high school formed the fourth boundary to the north. Â The ground was uneven, more hilly than flat, and there were still large stones here and there, and a seemingly out of place play structure for the grade schoolers.

It was an odd thing.Â  So often, nature was transplanted into a city, and it was new and inauthentic, made overly neat.Â  Trees, lawns, flowers.Â  Here, the nature was rough and unpolished, the city itself new and somewhat artificial in how overly tidy it was, untouched by time or elements.

A sports field in the middle section separated the grade schoolersâ€™ area from the theater. Â It was a stage in the old Roman style, slabs of stone set into the ground like stairs, stepping down as they got closer to the stage, where the platform sat.

Hundreds of students had gathered on the stone seats, and more stood around the top edge of the theater, watching and listening.Â  They were our survivors, our next generation.Â  Not so different from the crowd Iâ€™d had to deflect earlier.Â  A third of them still wore the very simple clothes that were handed out with supplies in the tent cities.Â  Some had even taken to strategically ripping and dressing up those clothes.Â  I didnâ€™t fault them for it.Â  It was hot.

A speaker carried the voice to those of us on the top edge.

The teachers of the school were on the stage, but they werenâ€™t speaking. Â It was a series of community leaders and volunteers instead.

â€œâ€¦And I make that a guarantee to you,â€ a man in an orange vest was saying. â€œIf you take those credentials, bring good shoes and work clothes, and if you donâ€™t screw around, you can walk into any lot and you can be working within the hour and get your pay by that dayâ€™s end. Â Good pay. Â You can do whatever you want, after school, but youâ€™ll always have this as a fallback, youâ€™ll have the security of being able to walk into a lot and have a job waiting for you. Â We can always use more hands.â€

Not enough seats at this school either. Â High school was and might well continue to be a half-day thing. Â The people on the stage were telling the kids their other options for the other half of the day.

I spotted Gilpatrick on the stage. Â He wore a black t-shirt and gray pants with boots, and in the summer heat he was sweating a fair amount. Â He had no hair on his head, but he had a five oâ€™clock shadow well before five oâ€™clock, bushy eyebrows and thick hair on thick forearms. Â Everyone else looked like they were trying to make their best pitch, in dressing nice and wearing smiles. Â Gilpatrick looked like he was trying to scare his prospects away.

Some of the non-prospects were standing around the upper edge, looking down at the new students and the stage. Â Most were senior students whoâ€™d picked what theyâ€™d do with their half-days last year, now waiting to induct the others. Â Some were siblings of those seniors, or younger friends. Â Others were like me, miscellaneous staff for miscellaneous roles.

I joined them.

â€œWe wondered if youâ€™d bailed,â€ Jasper said. Â He was very much a teenager, with acne, thin chin-hair and black hair that had had product in it, that had turned spiky from sweat.

â€œDelayed by a car accident.â€

â€œEveryoneâ€™s okay?â€ he asked.

â€œYep.â€Â  Insofar as anyone is okay.Â  â€œHas Gil done his five pounds of gun thing?Â  I was kind of looking forward to it, itâ€™s so corny.â€

â€œI think heâ€™s saving it for the deeper explanation later. Â He mostly talked about how he was going to make it his objective to make people quit, he isnâ€™t going to pay anyone, job prospects suck, heâ€™s going to make people march in the heat and the cold for miles while carrying unreasonable burdens. Â The â€˜five poundsâ€™ speech isnâ€™t bad, you know. Â It gets through to the kids,â€ Jasper said. Â For all that he was defending the speech, he smirked a bit.

â€œIt gets through to most,â€ Cubs said. Â He was a big guy, tall, broad-shouldered, fit, with his hair cut short. Â He thought for a second and then amended his statement, â€œsome.â€

â€œUs,â€ Jasper said.

â€œGuess so, yeah,â€ Cubs said.

I didnâ€™t miss the glance he shot at the girl at the far end of our little sub-group. Â Cami wore an expression I might have termed â€˜resting angry faceâ€™.Â  Perpetually pissed.

All three of them, and many other members of the group besides, were dressed in similar shades as Gilpatrick.Â  Blacks and grays.

â€œIâ€™m going to duck into my office,â€ I said.Â  â€œI want to check my email and make sure itâ€™s nice and neat if anyone stops in.â€

â€œOnly a short bit before we migrate over,â€ Cubs said. â€œOne more speaker.â€

â€œIâ€™ll let Gilpatrick know youâ€™re there,â€ Jasper said. Â He extended a fist. Â I rolled my eyes and instead of tapping it with my own, pushed it away.Â  Jasper smiled.

My destination wasnâ€™t in the high school, but was across the street. Â It was an open building with a partial second floor. Â The main floor was hardwood, with mats folded and piled up at the side. Â A few more senior students were already there- some were just entering or leaving the showers. Â It seemed like a good idea for cooling down, but I didnâ€™t have the time.

I waved at some of the seniors in passing and headed up the stairs.Â  The stairwell ran up one wall, unbounded by barriers, so it offered a view of everything below.

My office was the closest thing I had to a home, in this world. Â It was narrow and long, with a bookshelf at the right wall, a desk, computer and chair. Â Some boxes were piled up in the corners.

The bookshelf was my accomplishment. Â My fingers ran along the spines of books and other texts. Â Many of the works were collections of articles or official documents, bound by hand with a three-hole punch, rings, and patience.

Parahuman science. Â University textbooks, old workbooks with notes- not all mine. Â There were important articles, copied to plain text and printed out, with a lean toward the sciences, the nuances, the big revelations and reveals.

Official files.Â  Classification documents.Â  Then there were the notes for case one, case fifteen, case thirty-two, case fifty-three, case ninety.Â  The â€˜casesâ€™ were the events the PRT had deemed of interest.Â  Riddles both solved and unsolved.Â  My collection there was incomplete, but some were official enough to be confidential, and Iâ€™d never had that access.Â  Others were closed, the mystery deemed nonexistent or something to be folded into popular knowledge.

I had other files. Â There were names on those files. Â Whittler, Bilious, King Crow were some of the many on the shelf Iâ€™d deemed â€˜independentsâ€™. Â For teams, there were ones like the Ambassadors, Green Tea, N.N., Ossuary, Empire Eighty-Eight, and the Clans.Â  Iâ€™d made it a priority to collect those.Â  I worried we might need them.

On the bottom shelf, I had my magazines. Â Costumes Under Clothes, Gleam, Heroines, Masque, Shine On. Â Some of the boxes in the corner had my latest haul. Â Much of it would be duplicates. Â Maybe Iâ€™d give some of them out to seniors.

I could still smell a faint mildewy smell, and promised myself Iâ€™d identify the source when I had time. Â Iâ€™d left the window open, and the weather was warm, which was helping. Â A lot of this was what Iâ€™d salvaged from the office back home; Iâ€™d retrieved it from boxes and filing cabinets and hauled it here over a dozen trips. Â Iâ€™d rigged up tarps to keep the water off that corner of the house, but some of that moisture had been coming up from below. Â I would have to find the source of the smell and transcribe the text before throwing it out.

Maybe I could get Gilpatrick to get a kid who needed punishing to do it for me.

Information was too important. Â Even if that information was from the glossy, superficial magazines about superheroines that had been pitched to girls just like me eight to ten years ago.

Faint smells aside, I could draw in a deep breath and feel muscles from shoulder to calf relax.Â  This was more of that seventy percent part of the seventy percent fit where the job suited me.

That thirty percent, though. Â I wouldnâ€™t stay here forever. Â I hoped. Â It had been a thing that Iâ€™d hoped would look good on my college applications.Â  That hadnâ€™t worked.

I could hear the commotion as the mob of kids started coming in downstairs.

I walked over to my computer and booted it up. Â It booted up instantly, but the connection to the internet took a while. Â I opened a notebook and began searching through it.

I found the name before the internet succeeded in connecting. Â I closed the conversation from the day prior and waited for the internet before composing an email.

To: Deferent.I@Mail
Subject: Damaged pillar

I knew him, even just seeing his legs.Â  Or I knew of him, to be precise.Â  Yeah, based on what I knew of Fume Hoodâ€™s group, they might be outclassed.

The big guy was the Lord of Loss.Â  There were two ways a cape could go with a name like that.Â  The most obvious was to fuck up just once, and forever after have people wondering out loud what he was thinking, taking a name like that.Â  Being called a loser.

The other way was to succeed and ascend the name, to take that name and make it a title.Â  The Lord of Loss had managed that.

â€œAlright,â€ he said.

One of the issues of being a parahuman was that there wasnâ€™t a history to build on or a peerage to draw from. Â We had powers, yes. Â Some of those powers were similar to the powers others had, but there were almost always tricks and caveats, strengths one person had that another didnâ€™t. Â I couldnâ€™t copy Alexandriaâ€™s old tactics and style because my invincibility worked differently. Â Timing was so much more important to me.

I could be shot, if my timing was wrong, or if their timing was especially right.

A person like Jasper could take classes in martial arts and get lessons on the range, and he could use tools and draw on the experience of millions of others who had bodies that worked like his did, a set of capabilities that were virtually identical to his own.

There was only one Victoria Dallon with Victoria Dallonâ€™s powers. Â I had to lean heavily on my own experience.Â  In exercising my abilities, there was a point beyond which I was the only person that could teach myself â€“ nobody resembled me closely enough to be an instructor in how to fight, how to process, or how to or pass on their experience.

But my own experience was a drawback if I was caught in the moment, where I had to rely on instinct but that instinct pointed me right back to my old ways.

These people were innocent.Â  The officer, the others at the door.Â  Maybe some had been protesters.Â  Kingdom Come had no issue in using them, but I couldnâ€™t hurt his pawns.

He could have moved them as a group, but he didnâ€™t.Â  He moved like a chessmaster played chess.Â  One person taking a new position, pausing, checking the area, then another person moving.Â  The police officer in charge -chief or sheriff, I wasnâ€™t sure-Â  had stopped in the center of the room.Â  Others were moving around the perimeter.

I caught a glimpse of one by the gun he was holding, and moved around the corner.Â  They all moved the same way when they moved, pistols held up, gripped in two hands that were dotted in drops of drying blood, pointed at the ceiling.Â  I saw the gun before I saw the rest of him.

The lullaby continued, faint and distant.Â  It wasnâ€™t enough to obscure any scuffle I made.Â  I didnâ€™t want to make noise, and whatever the movies showed, it was hard to crawl around while wearing boots and be sure to not make any sound.

I didnâ€™t like flying.Â  I wasnâ€™t confident in it like I had been.Â  Two years had passed in the hospital, and my sense of flight had been as disturbed as the movement of my arm or my attempts at vocalization.Â  It was supposed to be back, but it was a muscle I hadnâ€™t exercised.

I wanted to fly, but it was tainted.

I raised myself off the ground, still hunched over, staying low enough that the counters would block me from sight, and used flight as much as light pushes on the sides of the cabinet to propel myself away from the advancing gunman.

I had other training to draw on that wasnâ€™t self-taught.Â  There was what Iâ€™d learned and absorbed from time with family, but that whole experience was so full of pitfalls I barely wanted to touch on it.

The Wards.Â  I hadnâ€™t been with them for long. Â Iâ€™d absorbed some things from Dean, because I lived the cape stuff and Dean was willing to teach it.Â  Iâ€™d studied up and Iâ€™d taken the tests.Â  I knew the numbers and the labels.Â  I knew the approach formations for squads.Â  Simple, making conflict with parahumans as textbook as possible, black ink on white paper, sans serif.

In fighting that perpetual battle of trying to think things through and still act in time, the classifications were a nice shortcut.Â  Apply the label, assume what worked against most people of one classification, and if it clearly didnâ€™t, it was still a starting point.

He was edging closer.

Kingdom Come was a breaker and a master.Â  He had a toggled state that changed the rules as they pertained to him.Â  Shake, blow up, and he was now a horde of people controlled by the bodily fluids on them. Â Masters were second highest priority as targets, breakers were targets that required timing, often hitting them when they were in the state that they were weakest.

Kingdom Come made that complicated by not giving me a body to target.

They were closing in.Â  Theyâ€™d crossed the length of the room and if I had to guess, four of them were standing within fifteen feet of me, guns held high, where it would be that much harder for me to lunge for the weapon.Â  He didnâ€™t have perfect coordination of their movements, I had to assume, unless they were all doing the same thing, like when the crowd had turned their heads.

The old me would have dealt with this by blitzing them.Â  Hit each hard, fast, before they had a chance to react.Â  Some minor harm would have come to innocents, but the situation would be resolved.

The current me waited, staying silent, letting them get close.Â  One to my left, one in the middle avenue of the kitchen, between the two rows of counter-islands, and one on the far right, furthest from me.

He spun around, looking, and I took advantage, leaping over the counter, reaching for the gun he held aloft.Â  I seized it and his hands, and pulled both to the ground, where the counters kept us out of sight of the other two.

It gave me a momentâ€™s pause to think.Â  I ignored the man Iâ€™d brought to the ground, as I held his hands and the gun.Â  I didnâ€™t even need my strength- only leverage and my body weight.

I tackled him to the ground, holding him as we went down to keep the impact from being too hard.Â  Iâ€™d managed to get one hand around his wrist, and as he pulled his other hand away, gripping the gun, I seized that wrist too.

Daybreak â€“ 1.6

Snagâ€™s power hurt, and it hurt in a way that had nothing to do with shedding blood or breaking bones.Â  Emotion.Â  My body still reacted, my heart rate picking up, breathing choked, adrenaline churning, hormones shifting.Â  My thoughts were scattered, thrusting me into a state where I could either only reel or I could grope for a position in familiar ground.

Fly then.

Sheâ€™d been nowhere to be found too.

Iâ€™d arrived alone, no help to offer.Â  Too late to say anything or hear anything from him.Â  Iâ€™d choked on my words when it came to saying something to his parents.Â  Thereâ€™d been this feeling like I couldnâ€™t react the way Iâ€™d wanted and needed to, because his parents were there and they were somehow maintaining their composure.Â  Upset, yes, but they were wealthy and dignified enough they would do their crying in private.Â  They had weathered their losses years before and it had been the same then, according to Dean.Â  Now it was on Deanâ€™s behalf.

What options did that leave me?Â  Break down into hysterical sobbing and act like I was hurting more than his own family was?Â  It might have been dismissed as the drama of a teenager and I hadnâ€™t wanted that to be the final note on Dean and me, in their eyes, in the eyes of bystanders.

Like I imagined anyone in a relationship did, Iâ€™d wondered if we were in love, and then Iâ€™d known we were in love, and Iâ€™d grown close enough to him to wonder if he was a soulmate, dismissed the term just as easily as it had come up because it was silly and it didnâ€™t matter either way, did it?Â  Iâ€™d received my answer on the question as Iâ€™d felt a part of me die during those long minutes of me trying and failing to say something to his family.
