Painful, in its own way, to have nobody to turn to.Â  The hurt had been there like a block of ice, melting too slowly when I hadnâ€™t had any warmth to reach out for, not any less cold as the water pooled.Â  Not any less for the time that passed.Â  Justâ€¦ more ambient.

This was like that.Â  Snagâ€™s emotional effect was temporary.Â  The pain ebbed out, made my fingers feel numb and tingly, made it hard to breathe, and made me feel more physically weak and less coordinated than I should have been.

I stumbled a few steps, and reached out to touch the wall for support as I resumed moving, entering the room Snag had been in when heâ€™d punched his arms through the wall.Â  It was reminiscent of a hotel room, but rustic enough it could have been a bed and breakfast.Â  Two small beds, a bedside table, a desk, and a flatscreen television sitting on a dresser.

He had a mover classification, I was pretty sure.Â  Heâ€™d used a trick to jump after the bus.Â  I made sure to look up, to avoid any ambush in case he jumped at me from the space between the top of the door and the ceiling.

â€œSnag?â€ I asked.

There was something very human about the desire to gather around a fire.Â  Power rationing meant every household had only a certain amount, more if there were more people in the house.Â  Conversely, there was a lot of cheap firewood.Â  Streetlights flickered on, and many house lights went off.Â  In back yards there were three other families on the city block that were gathering around fire pits.Â  Two of the families were playing different kinds of music, but it wasnâ€™t too discordant.Â  There were trees in each yard, front and back, and that helped to dampen the sound.

The entire street smelled like burning charcoal, and the light from the streetlights was just a little bit hazy with the ambient smoke.

It was a nice neighborhood, even if it had what I felt was the artificial quality.Â  Houses with character, sufficiently different from one another in style and architecture, but still so new that they looked more like movie sets than lived-in places.Â  Time and clutter would wear at those crisp edges.Â  Paint and attention would turn fences of new wood with the occasional edge still frayed from the sawâ€™s touch into something more personal.

This was the flip side to the hostility and the street-wide gap between protester and community center.Â  Boyfriend and girlfriend sat on an outdoor love seat together, arms around each other, bathed in fireâ€™s warmth.Â  Friends sat and talked, beers in hand.Â  Kids in another yard played with their dog.

With the path Iâ€™d taken, I reached the backyard first.Â  The driveway was wider than it was long, crushed gravel, with room for multiple vehicles, and a fence stretched from the house at one corner to the garage at the other.Â  My mom had invited neighbors, so it was a thing, even if things had reached a more relaxed point.

My dad sat on one of the lawn chairs, fire pit in front of him with the fire having burned down to just glowing coals.Â  The barbecue was to his right, lid open, tiny bits of meat clinging to the grill.

He was forty-two but looked younger.Â  The fact that he was as fit as he was played into it- only the white in his beard stubble really gave it away.Â  His hair, too, was short.Â  He was the only one who hadnâ€™t put a sweatshirt or jacket on, owing to the proximity of the two heat sources- he was wearing a t-shirt that was form-fitting in a way that showed off his muscles.Â  Pretty darn gross, given he was a dad,Â  my dad, and he was supposed to dress his age.Â  I would have insisted on clothes that hid any sign of muscle at all, really, had I been given a say.

He looked relaxed though.Â  As relaxed as Iâ€™d seen him in a while, really, and Iâ€™d seen him passed out on the couch back at the apartment.

She was smiling.Â  She folded one knee over the other, then a moment later was undoing the position, both feet on the porch again as she leaned forward, laughing at something someone had said.

I dropped the forcefield.Â  I sank back into my seat, and it protested the landing.

Not a second trigger.Â  I was well aware of that.Â  When Iâ€™d first had my forcefield, it hadnâ€™t protected my costume.Â  I had two theories as to why.

The first theory was that Iâ€™d grown, and the boundaries that the forcefield used to define â€˜meâ€™ had changed.Â  Iâ€™d breathe out, breathe in, gain a pound here, lose a pound there, and it would adjust for the maximum bounds.Â  It didnâ€™t explain how my skirt was often protected, but Iâ€™d mused on that too, that my legs moved, my hair had been long at one point, Iâ€™d been shorterâ€¦

Iâ€™d been that, the forcefield had adjusted, and that was the new upper bound of what I was, forever with me.

It felt thin, as theories went.

The second theory was that it was the Manton effect, that broad-as-bells term for the built in protections and limitations of the power.Â  The theory was that the built-in protections of the power only protected what I saw as a part of me, and it had taken some time before the costume was that much a part of my identity.

That that was me, now, as much as the costume I wore.

I couldnâ€™t be that.Â  I couldnâ€™t sit still and be crushed under the weight of that thing.

I needed to do something, and taking books off the shelves felt like it was moving backward, not forward.

I spun around in my seat, and I loaded up the webpage.Â  Something to do.Â  Methodically filling out details on the group Iâ€™d seen, researching, filling myself in, and letting others know what they were up against.

Something constructive to keep me occupied until the power ran out, or until I was so tired I had no choice but to sleep.

Daybreak â€“ 1.8

Daylight streamed in at a low angle as I stepped back into my office.Â  The light was blurred as it came through the condensation on the window, spotted with dots of darkness due to the melted frost that still clung to the windowâ€™s surface in lines and constellations of droplets.Â  Ninety percent of my books were packed up, the boxes that were still here were stacked near the door and the bookshelf, labeled in thick marker, with shorthand notes on the most interesting and essential files within written on the boxes in pen.Â  Iâ€™d left a few of the more interesting files available.Â  Iâ€™d put them in a box on their own, in case I needed something to read.

I was freshly showered, towel around my hair, and Iâ€™d gotten dressed in a slightly musty spare change of clothes.Â  I had a blanket, candles, and a computer booting up.Â  I watched as it started the struggle of fighting every other computer out there that was wanting a piece of the web.

I slid my to-do list across the desk until it was beside my keyboard.Â  Iâ€™d need a car.Â  Plenty of people were willing to offer the use of theirs in order to pay for fuel.Â  Food, a place to stay.

Living accommodations might be tricky.Â  Demand was high, and it was a pretty steep drop in quality from the central areas and the fringes.Â  Many companies were putting up five or more houses a day or an apartment complex over the course of a week, slapping them together like there was a gun to their heads.Â  When it came time to find renters, they were more interested in filling the spaces fast.Â  They had no reason to answer questions or have a potential buyer investigating the nooks and crannies or checking the plumbing if they could turn that person away and have someone else on their doorstep within minutes.

It was a minefield.Â  Word of mouth, cash, contacts, or luck were required to get a proper house that wouldnâ€™t start falling apart after the fact.Â  Fume Hood was one of the ones whoâ€™d been unlucky.

Flare â€“ 2.3

â€œEvacuate!â€

The massed crowd of citizen workers was to my right, the people with powers to my left.Â  Half of the light sources in and around the clearing had broken, and the only other illumination came from the effects of powers.Â  A common thread ran through all of it.Â  Energy spilled out and created matter where it splattered on the road, materials sprouted from nothing, streaked with thin streams of liquid that glowed like fire, and more abstract growths formed suspended in air, their images sticking to the backs of my eyes like the persistent afterimages of sparklers waved in the dark.

People were shouting.Â  Some were screaming.Â  I couldnâ€™t make much of it out.

I flew to the far side of the clearing, which also happened to have some of the thickest gatherings of people.Â  They had been citizen laborers, gathering to make their displeasure known to the construction groups.Â  Theyâ€™d been facing the building until the incident, theyâ€™d backed up, and there were places where the presence of buildings and parked vehicles made it so they had no place to retreat, leaving them now packed together, shoulder to shoulder, front to back, jostling.

Iâ€™d helped to evacuate before.Â  I had attended the Leviathan attack on my hometown.Â  I had been around for the majority of the Slaughterhouse Nine crisis.Â  Iâ€™d participated in other, minor incidents, helping with fires and storms, though those had mostly involved helping the elderly and standing around.

The truism was that in a disaster, people were their own worst enemies.

Never this bad.

Iâ€™d never seen or imagined a situation where people would do the opposite of evacuating, throwing themselves headlong into the hazard.Â  They thought the people in the center of the clearing were getting powers, and people were breaking away from the crowd at the clearingâ€™s edge to run toward the affected individuals.

Crystal created a wall to block off a street as she passed it.Â  She wouldnâ€™t be able to keep it up as she got further away, but it bought time for others to get there.

She raked a laser across the road, a bright and noticeableÂ  distraction, to give people pause.

I dropped to the street, using a pulse of my aura to get peopleâ€™s attention.Â  Some stopped to look, while others ducked low, as if instinct drove them to shy away from the perceived threat.

â€œRun!â€ I shouted, using my aura to play up my words.Â  â€œOther way!â€

I saw eyes widen, and turned to look.Â  A man had opened his mouth, and had something that looked almost as tall and thick as a telephone pole spearing skyward from his mouth.Â  Blood streamed from the sides of his mouth, his jaw clearly dislocated, and more fluids painted the length of the pole as it continued to rise.Â  It reached its maximum height, and then forked, the upper half splitting out into two equally thick portions, a giant â€˜Yâ€™ shape.Â  Each branch then forked into two, and forked into two again.

â€œGo,â€ I said, sparing only a momentary glance for the people Iâ€™d been stopping.Â  I saw them start to run away.

The man reached up, his fingers dragging along the blood-slick shaft of the trunk of the fractal tree he had vomited up.Â  Each movement of his hands was slower and weaker than the last.

I flew toward him, to do what I could to help, even though I wasnâ€™t sure what that could possibly be.

The â€˜treeâ€™ toppled, and it was only because I was already on my way toward him that I was able to intervene.Â  I reached out for the falling tree, and my power was quicker to touch it.Â  Phantom fingers bit into the surface, fracturing the chalky material.Â  With flight, my bare hands, my power, and my aura pushed out to give people a little more incentive to get out of the way, I controlled the treeâ€™s fall.Â  It broke into chunks on contact with the ground.Â  One of the people with new powers was pinned beneath branches, but it didnâ€™t look like he was hurt by the contact.

I flew to the man whoâ€™d grown the tree.Â  Even before I reached his side, I could see the damage that had been done.Â  Jaw, throat, chest, and stomach had been torn away.Â  Traces of the same material that had formed the tree had collected in his insides and pelvis, breaking into jagged pieces at some point before or during the treeâ€™s fall.

He had no throat to feel for a pulse.Â  I wasnâ€™t about to rule anything out, even as I saw the remains of his heart in his splayed-out chest cavity.Â  I pried one of his eyes open, and I saw no response.

I went from a crouch to airborne in a second.

That particular disaster had been dramatic and visible for a significant portion of the people nearby.Â  Most were thinking twice about running toward the epicenter.

When was the next wave coming?Â  The number of people to trigger all at once had seemed to double the last time.Â  They didnâ€™t look like multi-triggers either.Â  One power each, some self-destructive.Â  I could hear the screams and shouts of a lot of unhappy people and I couldnâ€™t see one person who looked particularly happy about their new ability.

I flew to a new location, looking to see where I could get the most people away.Â  The tree had done my work for me in one spot, Laserdream was standing at the intersection of two streets and walling them off with red-tinted, translucent fields.

I saw another group- people were pulling away from the crowd, which was actively trying to grab them and hold them back.Â  Young people â€“ older teenagers and twenty-somethings, that might have been a group of friends.Â  Seven of them.

I shouted, but my voice was drowned out by the dentist-drill scream of a power somewhere nearby, by the hollers, the warnings, a dull explosion.

I used my aura again.Â  Several people in the group stumbled, so caught up in reacting to my aura that they lost track of where they were going or how to put one foot in front of the other.Â  Several others paused, helping their friends that had tripped, stopped, or fallen.Â  The people at the edge of the crowd reacted too, pulling back away from me.

Iâ€™d hoped more of them would stop shouting and screaming.Â  The affected people and the people at the edge of the clearing were making so much noise that it nearly drowned me out as I shouted, â€œGet back!â€

A number of people listened.Â  The crowd in particular was inclined to take my order, getting away from the scene.Â  Two of the seven whoâ€™d lagged behind the others turned to go too.

Five, however, looked at me and then continued to run toward the scene.

I clenched my fist.

Rationally, I knew that they likely saw this as the simplest thing in the world.Â  The people over there had powers; all they had to do to get powers was to head over there.Â  Some might well have no idea what triggers were, or they might have bought into one of the various other theories out there, some intentionally obscuring the truth.Â  They didnâ€™t know better.

Well, the screaming should have given them pause, but that might have been balanced out by the fact that they felt especially powerless at this time in particular.Â  Because we were only two years after the most catastrophic and traumatic loss of human life in history.Â  Because as much as we were recovering, we were far from being where weâ€™d been.Â  We werenâ€™t okay.Â  The dispute between the citizen workers and the construction administrations only brought that home.

Rationally, I knew that.

Less rationally, I had a weak point that extended well before the Gold Morning, well before the hospital stay, well before the Slaughterhouse Nine, before the bad days against Empire Eighty-Eight, before my trigger, even.Â  Iâ€™d spent a fair portion of my time post-trigger and especially in the hospital, thinking about it.

I couldnâ€™t fucking stand being ignored.

I flew to intercept.

I hadnâ€™t practiced with this power enough.Â  Even using it was a hard reminder, with a mental and emotional cost.Â  I knew I needed to come to terms with it, and my time at the hospital had been an early foray into that.

That had been flight, and my flight was more or less untouched.

I flew low, approaching a car.Â  As with the tree, all of my powers were up and active as I reached out in the carâ€™s direction.Â  Phantom hands dug into the metal of the carâ€™s body, invisible fingers stabbing through.Â  A mass of something pressed down on the hood, caving it in.

If I had any control over those limbs, it wasnâ€™t something that lent itself to fine touches.Â  It didnâ€™t work well with the careful, methodical, warrior monk approach.Â  In this, in the instinct and the moment of frustration, I could only hope that what I wanted and what my power wanted were mostly in agreement.

I glanced up to make sure Laserdream wasnâ€™t watching.Â  I was close enough for my fingertips to brush the carâ€™s paint as I swept my arm to one side, the holes and dents in the car twisting or opening wider as the phantom grip adjusted.Â  The- the other Victoria, the phantom Victoria that had never left the hospital, the wretch, threw the car.

I canceled my power momentarily, to force it to release its hold, so it wouldnâ€™t fling the car into the people I was trying to stop.Â  I let it reactivate a half-second later, flying forward in the carâ€™s direction.Â  My defenses were up and sufficient to let me adjust the carâ€™s trajectory with a sharp kick to the side.Â  Just to be safe.

It crashed into a parked car, upside down, its roof and windows shearing into the top of the other.Â  A loud impact, metal scraping metal, a dozen windows on the two vehicles breaking.Â  It was raucous, chaotic, sudden and surprising, in a stark contrast to the massive, enduring weight that seemed to settle in me.

Harder than flying.Â  I could tell myself I was helping people, keeping them clear of danger, and it helped much as it had with the flying, but it was still hard.

The fact that a car had flown into another car twenty feet in front of them was enough to stop them in their tracks.Â  I had their full attention now.

â€œGet away!Â  Itâ€™s dangerous!â€

â€œGet away!â€

The fragment of a trigger vision hit me.Â  The latest wave.

I saw only a flash of faces, and in seeing those faces, I saw the phantom self that clung to me.Â  The impression lingered for only a moment before I realized the faces didnâ€™t resemble mine.

The man had been springing forward from the car to the ground when the event had hit.Â  I saw his legs swing forward, while his head remained in place.Â  He dangled, suspended in the air.

I picked myself up off the ground, flying to him.

Gone already.Â  No pulse, no light behind the eyes.Â  He made a faint gurgling sound, but it was some biological process or symptom of what had happened, not a sign of life.Â  He was pissing himself and shitting himself in death.

He dropped out of the air, and I caught him.Â  It hardly mattered, he was gone, but it didnâ€™t feel right to just let him fall.Â  I eased him to the ground.

â€œPlease help!â€ I heard a guy shout, amid renewed and nearby whimpers and sobs.

A woman screamed words that barely strung together, the heel of one hand pressed to her forehead.Â  The other was pointed forward.Â  She shot something that was only visible by the way light refracted at its edges.Â  The projectile hit the ground, carrying forward like a cartoon mole and the elongated, humped trail of dirt it left in its wake.Â  Unlike the mole, the hump was jagged, folded earth.Â  Road folded up like complex origami.Â  She was pinning people down, keeping them from exiting a building.

âŠ™

Sleep eluded me.Â  I stood on the balcony, I stared out at a city without nearly enough lights or light in it, a jagged and incomplete skyline, and I tried to shake a persistent melancholy I couldnâ€™t put my finger on.

The day had been a good one.Â  My friendship with Sveta rekindled, with Sveta doing as well as I could hope for, possibilities for the future, interesting puzzles to work out, and Iâ€™d been able to do favors for people I cared about.

A part of it was the therapy.Â  It was strange, to be in a place mentally and emotionally where therapy had a cost to it, in a way.Â  The voice of Mrs. Yamada and the tone of the conversations reminded me of the darkest period in my life.Â  Those reminders were probably responsible for the nightmares that had torn me from sleep.

Maybe it would be good if I called the new therapist, a new voice.

It wasnâ€™t the nightmares that kept me from getting back to sleep, but a restless nagging feeling.Â  I liked problems I could decisively solve, things I could tell myself I had an answer for, something I could handle in the dawn, and then I could go back to sleep.Â  The feeling that had settled with me wasnâ€™t that sort of answerable question.

It was the restless nagging that had me carefully and slowly open the sliding door of the balcony, step into the living room, and gather some things.Â  A bag with my wallet and things, fresher clothes, the mask Iâ€™d worn for the broken trigger incident.

I went flying, and my destination wasnâ€™t one that would answer the nagging feeling, but one that could answer other, more concrete questions.Â  With luck, Iâ€™d be able to distract myself.

There were cities and areas Iâ€™d considered for the therapy groupâ€™s expedition.Â  Ones in need, ones I knew didnâ€™t fall neatly in one jurisdiction or another.Â  I used the highways and major roadways as my waypoints, so I wouldnâ€™t pass them or find myself flying too far north or south.

The sun was rising by the time I reached the first.Â  Sherwood span.Â  Too low a population, I could tell right away.Â  Too many farms, the houses too spread out.

It took me twenty minutes to reach the next.Â  The area was slow to wake up, which was a surprise, given the amount of construction sites I could see from above.Â  Usually the work started first thing.

It was a nice slice of city, with a view of the water, tall buildings, shiny, modern, with nice, large houses, but it was only halfway erected.Â Â Â  There were cars in driveways, but there wasnâ€™t much life.

I flew low, stopping at one of the gates to a construction site for a taller building.

Laminated sheets had been put up on the gates.

Construction suspended until weâ€™re given what weâ€™re owed.

The same was on display in other places, with laminated sheets of paper and graffiti.Â  Some of it was angrier.

I was reading a very bold, large bit of text about how certain people should be choking on cocks, when I saw I had company, standing in the corner of my field of view.Â  A cape.

I turned to face them.

Not anyone I recognized.Â  A man in armor with spikes on it.Â  Plate mail, and plate armor was hard to get done right, especially in this modern day.Â  He carried no weapon I could see.Â  Spiky plate armor wasnâ€™t exactly original or new, either.

He didnâ€™t say anything or do anything, but he was holding a piece of paper.

I approached him, my forcefield up.Â  He didnâ€™t budge.

â€œWhatâ€™s this?â€

â€œGot it,â€ I said.Â  I looked around.Â  â€œQuiet town.â€

When my head was turned, he reached for my throat.

â€œOur town,â€ he said.

That said, he trudged off.

I watched him go, and then I walked in the opposite direction.Â  People were watching from doorsteps with coffee in hand, or standing by cars, now.

I didnâ€™t want to back down or look weak, not if this was possibly a place I might be visiting with any regularity, so I walked slowly, like I wasnâ€™t bothered.

Turn around and fly home, Glory Hole

Theyâ€™d asked around, huh?

I folded the paper up, and I held the folded square as I walked, thinking, observing.Â  A slice of city, paralyzed, a clear villain presence.

Iâ€™d left Brockton Bay in the middle of a situation, or Iâ€™d been taken from the city during.Â  Iâ€™d put in the hours and put heart and soul into trying to combat the badness that was taking over the city, and at the end of the day, I hadnâ€™t ever enjoyed a resolution to that situation.Â  Iâ€™d never felt like Iâ€™d made enough of a difference in the end result.

But this wasnâ€™t about me.Â  It was about those teenagers and kids in Yamadaâ€™s group.

A sign was erected by one construction site.Â  It was covered in graffiti.Â  â€˜Cedar Point Apartmentsâ€™ was written at the top, but â€˜Cedarâ€™ had been covered over in paint, and â€˜Hollowâ€™ had been written in its place.

Flare â€“ Interlude 2

â€œLong coat, long hair, just got through the door, has a gun,â€ Crystalclear said, thumb on the button of his walkie-talkie.

The reply from the officers was almost impossible to make out.

The status quo in quiet periods was for there to be two thinkers on duty at all times. Â They were meant to be in communication and watching each otherâ€™s backs, and they were meant to be cooperating with the officers stationed at the portal.

During the quieter times, it would have been less than perfect for his partner to be in the midst of the crowd, where it took effort for Crystalclear to keep track of him and watch the manâ€™s back.

Relay, one of his new teammates.

It wasnâ€™t a quiet period, as one of the dayâ€™s bigger trains had just arrived. Â There were supposed to be four people on duty, one shift nearly over, another just beginning, for twice the number of eyes and powers on the scene.

Yes, it could have been an accident that the other two had yet to arrive. Â But accidents and coincidences could just as easily be contrivances at the hands of masterminds.Â  The radios acting up didnâ€™t help matters.

â€œ-ot the gun, good ca-â€ the voice on the other side of the walkie talkie reported, the static cutting off the very beginning and the ending.

Crystalclearâ€™s vision didnâ€™t give him color that wasnâ€™t the blurring around the white outlines that defined everything. Â Red jacket meant nothing to him. Â But he could see the crowd, seeing everyone at once, and he could check the shoes. Â It took some focus to narrow things down, to look for the pointed shoes, to observe for another few moments to see who was grouped up.

Three people, all about the same age, all men. Â Their heads radiated with distortions. Â Their focus- not on anything in particular.Â  He saw what they were dwelling on as a series of fractures, distorted angles, and breaks that surrounded them.Â  These things suggested things about what was going on in their heads that were more limited to the moment, covering stresses in every sense of the word.

Stress as in emotional upset, stressing the importance of something, stress as in tension and wear.

He was glad he could use the landline for this. Â The little room was separated from the portal and train platforms by two walls, one with a one-way pane of glass set in it. Â The third wall was open, so he was free to step outside and be in the thick of things within seconds, without having to worry about doors or counters. Â Beside him was a phone and a computer he hadnâ€™t bothered to fiddle with â€“ he couldnâ€™t see the contents of the screen without pulling a crystal from his face.

He hit the button for channel one on the phone, then picked up.

â€œRelay reports thereâ€™s three people incoming. Â He got a low-level bad feeling about them. Â They seem stressed to me. Â Not an imminent danger. Â You might want to pull them out of line and have a chat. Â One in the lead has a red jacket, pointed shoes. Â Iâ€™ll give you more information on their positions once theyâ€™re settled in line.â€

â€œGot it. Â Thank you, Crystalclear.â€

â€œLet us know if you need anyone to sit in,â€ he said.

â€œWill do.â€

He was aware as heads throughout the crowd turned, their focus shifting to Relay, to the train, to the officers.Â  For most, the light around them refracted into kaleidoscopic structures, cone or beak shaped, pointed this way and that.Â  At the ends farthest from the points of focus, the open ends of the cones splayed out into nimbuses, auras, fractures.

He had been one of them, a year ago, a refugee stepping off the train to enter Earth Gimel, finding his luggage, walking up the short set of stairs to the desks, where people clustered in families and groups of friends, rather than in single file.Â  They would be interviewed, they would be given temporary identification, and they would get their packages with information and resources.

Unlike manyÂ  of them, he had waited nearly six months for access, because heâ€™d been open about the fact he had powers.Â  A mistake, because they had wanted to be careful, it had meant he had needed weeks and months of screens, of interviews and background checks, while other people passed through.

It wasnâ€™t the first time something like that had happened, where he had taken too long to put the pieces together.Â  All thinkers had their weaknesses and catches â€“ all powers, probably, but thinkers were what he was most familiar with, and thinkers almost always had their issues with the mind.Â  The problems of the mind were difficult to identify and fix, because they were so invisible, and the tools for diagnosis were often what part of what was broken or altered.

He had taken a considerable length of time to figure out the nuances of his power, too.Â  The most obvious aspect was that he could see through walls, but he lost the ability to see and understand people, to see their faces or easily grasp the clothes they wore.

There was so much more to it, and he was learning more of it every week and month.Â  The colors meant things, and he had only worked out the blues and the reds.Â  Other colors separated from the white at times.Â  There were a lot of greens in the crowd and along the station, pulling away from the outlines.Â  He had ideas about what they meant, but he couldnâ€™t say anything with confidence.

The fractures and formations in distortions around people were another part of it.Â  There were elements to the way things broke up and distorted that had deeper meaning, things he didnâ€™t understand in a way he could explain, but which made it easy for him to relate one personality and personality type to another, familiar one.

The portal took up much of the station in front of him.Â  His multifaceted senses covered the tract of Gimel surrounding the portal, and the areas of Bet on the far side.Â  His view encompassed the surroundings on the other side, the people, the terrain, and the different colors that bled out from the sharper white outlines.

Glare â€“ 3.1

Cities, like people, got their second chances.Â  Few cities had needed one so badly as this.Â  I was left hoping the other cities were doing better with their second opportunities, because nothing I was seeing was very promising, here.

The four teams under the Wardensâ€™ umbrella, now condensed down to three, were divided into those who wanted to return to the way things had been and those who wanted to forge a new way forward, learning from the mistakes of the past.Â  The appeal of returning to a semblance of what weâ€™d had was clear- we missed the foods, the places, the familiar businesses and media, the familiar faces.

We wanted normal and even now every meal, every soap we used, every piece of clothing, it was a reminder of how far from normal we were.Â  It was different and often less because we had less, and we had less of a footing.Â  I wasnâ€™t the only person who felt their stomach sink when we saw the news two weeks after the broken trigger had decimated the reconstruction workersâ€™ protest, saying that the transportation strike was imminent, and that factory workers were contemplating joining in, an across-the-board attempt to demand stability and structure.

It was important, a line had to be drawn and the endless talks about what our government would look like needed to end, but I still saw the reports and I knew the foods, clothes, and routine I wanted were going to have to wait that much longer.

That was one of the prevailing arguments for normal, for going back.Â  This section of the city, this settlement, was the counterpoint.

Brockton Bay had been a port, growing as the industry did.Â  A lot of what made it work as a fledgling port city made New Brockton work as one of our first footholds in Earth Gimel.Â  Lumber, quarrying, some surface level minerals, and geography protected from the harshest sweeps of cold weather from the north.

The industry had become a prominent part of the city, and then the greater industry had outgrown it.Â  Things had reached the point where it was easier to take one big ship and go to Boston and transport goods from there than to take two smaller ships and go to Brockton Bay, even if Brockton Bay was closer to the goodsâ€™ destination.Â  The factories and goods went where the ships went, because it wasnâ€™t sensible to ship raw materials from Boston to Brockton Bay to do manufacturing when Boston could handle it.

New Brockton felt like it sat on that brink between relevance and ruin.Â  As a settlement, it was defined by tall buildings and the edifices of heavy industry.Â  There were ships finding their way past each other on the water and big brick buildings with black plumes of smoke rising from their chimneys.Â  Already back to the ways of an era that predated me, cutting corners to produce more at a cost to tomorrow.Â  It was crowded and bursting at the seams, and it had been for a while now, trying to grow despite the constraints of water and mountain around it.

It didnâ€™t escape me that the settlement continued to chug along while the gears and belts of the greater megalopolis were grinding to a stop under strikes and shutdowns.

I walked, rather than fly, because the directions Iâ€™d been given mandated it.Â  I suspected it was intentional.Â  I knew there were eyes on me, I knew who some of those eyes belonged to, and I had strong suspicions about others.

The racist graffiti no longer dominated downtown, though I did see some, with half of it partially painted over or altered.Â  Many of the people who had lived and thrived in Brockton Bay had made their way here, after all.Â  An attempt had been made to use wall space, to give the tenements-and-factories color when mirrored windows on skycrapers didnâ€™t steal it from the sky or water.Â  Murals now decorated many of the walls and building fronts, no doubt an attempt to leave less open wall space for the gang tags and symbols.Â  Animals and symbols of humanity like clasped hands covered residential areas.Â  Green trees, branches, and lush mountains painted almost ironically on the sides of factories and power plants.

There were places that mirrored home, in layout and the buildings that had been placed.Â  The area that had been the Towers at the southwest corner of the city was still the Towers.Â  Downtown was still where Downtown had been.Â  A Lord Street stabbed north-to-south through the settlement.Â  Despite the attempts, it wasnâ€™t home.Â  It came from something different.

Such was the counterpoint: in attempting to paint a picture of home, we might distort or create a caricature of that picture.Â  If we rushed it or forced it, we risked making some of the same fundamental mistakes weâ€™d made before, building on cracked foundations.

Seeing the murals, the directions Iâ€™d received started to make sense.Â  The path was byzantine.Â  Go the way the wolf and his cubs are looking.Â  A wolf and three cubs that looked like they were made of white smoke were painted on a concrete wall.Â  They stood facing one way, but their heads were looking back.

Walk beneath the leaping rabbit.Â  A rabbit decorated an arch at the edge of a childrenâ€™s park.Â  The park felt small and lonely amid larger, taller buildings, partially fenced in, with room for two swings, a slide, a sandbox and one basketball half-court that would have to be vacated if a car came through to use the parking garage or if the dump truck came for the dumpster at the back of a building.

Follow the snake.

If I hadnâ€™t known it was a snake, I might not have realized what it was.Â  It was sectioned off, the skeleton of a winding serpent with each vertebrae several feet from the other.Â  Three white pieces along one wall, a white-painted drain cover, then more segments on the wall opposite.

The painted lines of a crosswalk took me across the street.Â  I followed more segments of the snake to reach one of the larger apartment complexes, four identical L-shaped buildings framing a plaza.Â  The bottom floors of the buildings and the lowest floors along the inside of each â€˜Lâ€™ had some basic stores.

Two years ago, this would have been one of the nicer areas in Earth Gimel, if a little basic.Â  No-name grocery store, clothing store, and home-goods store.Â  It was dated already, and I could already imagine two years from now, when various murals might be faded or defaced, when the metal chairs and tables would be rusted, the stores closed or forgotten.Â  The snake cut through the plaza, which could have seated two hundred people, but currently had six.Â  Any earlier and there would have been people having a late lunch.Â  Any later and it would be time for an early dinner or an after-work bite to eat.

A tunnel led through the body of one of the apartment buildings, leading from plaza to parking lot.Â  The mural of a cat with its back twisting and arching was painted on the walls and roof.Â  Its paws stuck out and across the footpath firmly pressed down on the snakeâ€™s neck.

â€˜Waitâ€™ was the last instruction.

I checked my phone.Â  One message:

K:

A train came, traveling west-to-east.Â  I knew Sveta and Tristan would be boarding it.Â  Had I been on foot, it was the one I would have caught.

I was prepared to follow him to Greenwich.Â  It was a lengthy trip, and it left me to think about grabbing dinner, possibly on the trip back.Â  I tempted myself with thoughts of a burger or a good souvlaki roll.Â  Something warm, as I thought on it.Â  This high up, there was no heat radiating up off the ground or nearby surfaces, less sunlight bouncing around with light energy dissipating and becoming heat, and the steady wind flowed past me to swipe the warmth that my body put out.Â  As stakeouts went, this was liable to be cold, and Iâ€™d have to figure out something for bathroom breaks.

As self-imposed missions went, it wasnâ€™t just hard for me to justify doing this, it was a pretty rough experience.Â  The mind-numbing dullness of a sit-and-watch stakeout combined with the hypnotic nature of a long-distance drive.Â  Drivers, at least, had to watch the road and be mindful of other drivers.Â  I had nothing to help keep my thoughts centered.

From Stratford to Bridgeport.Â  I had my binoculars out, and I watched for trouble, studying the people boarding the train.

Nothing obvious.

The train carried on its way, traveling from the Bridgeport neighborhood to Fairfield span, past the community center that had been attacked at Norfair, and then onward to Norwalk station.Â  Kenzieâ€™s neighborhood.

There were stops where only a pair of people left, stops where only a few got on, and Norwalk, unfortunately, was one of the major stations.Â  I couldnâ€™t track everyone that boarded.

My thoughts were preoccupied, thinking about what I was doing, my doubts, my frustration that I couldnâ€™t effectively watch out for trouble while doing this the way I was doing it.Â  It was too easy for someone with powers to board the train and go after Rain while uncostumed.Â  Was it likely?Â  No.Â  But I wanted to justify what I was doing.

There was a chance, though, that when Rain got off the train, he would be followed by fellow passengers until he was in a place where he could be attacked.Â  I could watch out for that.

I could watch out for any unexpected stops, and I could keep an eye out for the old staples of railway robberies and ambushes â€“ trains moved slowest when they went around corners, so I could keep an eye out for ambushes and unexpected boardings that took place in those locations.

With my thoughts caught up in things as they were, I nearly missed it.

The train was old-fashioned in look, cars linked by couplings, and passengers could move between cars, with the space between each car being open to the air.Â  Periodically passengers would step out to smoke or get fresh air.Â  Most were parents with kids.

At the caboose, a figure had stepped out onto the back.Â  Rain.

He climbed over the railing and jumped, while the train was going well over a hundred miles an hour.

Hands out to his side, his bag in one hand, other empty, his feet touched the slope, and he stopped.Â  No momentum, nothing to suggest heâ€™d been on a speeding train a matter of seconds ago.Â  The fact he stood on a slope didnâ€™t seem to matter, as he didnâ€™t slide, slip, or fall.

He looked around, but he didnâ€™t look up, and I wasnâ€™t sure he would have seen me if he had.Â  He jogged down the slope, and walked across a field.Â  Past the field was mostly wilderness and dirt road.

Rain walked for ten minutes to get where he was going.Â  Erin had parked under a modest little bridge in a town with one gas station.

â€œI donâ€™t know if I like what I saw earlier,â€ Brio said.Â  â€œBlessing might be a strong word.â€

â€œAll parahumans have their issues,â€ I said.

Brio seemed to consider for a moment.

He extended his hand to shake.

We shook it, each of us in turn.

No name yet, costumes to be decided, codenames to be determined.

But we were a team with a mission.Â  We were doing this.

Glare â€“ Interlude 3

Dot moved slowly and carefully through the store.Â  She placed a hand on the floor for the added balance and weight distribution, then slid the hand left to right and back again, pushing it through a layer of dust that gathered and tumbled onto the back of her hand.

She was glad for the fingerless glove she wore, because it let her feel the finer details while keeping it clean and warm.Â  The floor was cool and moist.Â  The exterior wall of the store was letting the rain in, and the rain traced a path through one portion of the store, cutting thin rivers through the dust.Â  Wet in places, dry in places, but persistently clammy and dirty.Â  Perpetually colorless.

It was the lack of color that got to her the most.

It was one of the big stores, where everything was gathered together into tall stacks and piles beneath and on metal racks.Â  The lights were fluorescent, and they flickered.Â  The buzzing sounds the lights made were more constant than the light.

A menacing sound.Â  Menacing, glaring lights.

It was safer to climb on the stacks of cardboard boxes than it was to walk on the floor or to make contact with the wood and metal of the shelves.

She paused as she climbed to a higher shelf, figuring out how best to ascend while minimizing dangerous contact.Â  Finally, she decided to take a risk by grabbing a metal cross-bar, hauling herself up, and setting her feet on a series of plastic bottles in cardboard trays, stacked higher than a man was tall.

She couldnâ€™t read well, but she could recognize the labels.Â  Pills.Â  Vitamins, probably.Â  If these were here, then there might be better offerings close by.Â  She searched the nearby piles until she found cardboard boxes with cartoon characters on the front.Â  Pictures of cartoon character heads were beside not-cartoon images in shiny monocolor shapes.

Dot opened a box, careful not to make noise, and fished inside.Â  A plastic bottle within, and inside the plastic bottleâ€¦ a colorful assortment of gummy vitamins.

She fished out the contents and pushed them into her mouth until she could barely close her jaw.Â  The artificial taste overpowered her nose and mouth.Â  Her eyes rolled back into her head with the effort of chewing.

A loud noise made her freeze.

The doors had been opened.Â  She heard loud footsteps.

She climbed deeper into the stacks of vitamins, listening and watching.

â€œHellooooo!â€ the call was drawn out.Â  Dot tensed, listening as the greeting bounced around the building interior.

Dot waited.

â€œAnyone here!?â€

She waited, silent, peering through the gaps between the cardboard boxes and plastic bottles.

Another voice could be heard saying, â€œLights are on and nobodyâ€™s home?â€

â€œThey could be out, or a group of refugees might have stopped in on their way to the portal.Â  They could have set up power and scavenged before leaving things behind for others.â€

Dot winced with every tromp of boot on tiled floor.Â  She could hear people rummaging, pulling down boxes and tearing into the contents.Â  Things fell to the ground.

She changed locations, putting some distance between herself and them.Â  It didnâ€™t help; their explorations meant they drew nearer to her as she lurked on a high shelf.

â€œâ€¦names you canâ€™t pronounce, grab that first.â€

â€œWhy?Â  Preservatives?â€

â€œPreservatives, yep.Â  Keep a close eye out for the products with the wrong names.â€

â€œWrong names?â€

â€œIf itâ€™s not called soap, but a â€˜cleansing barâ€™ that means itâ€™s so loaded with crud that they werenâ€™t legally allowed to call it soap.Â  That shit is gold to us, because the chemicals in it mean it lasts.Â  If it lasts, it can be resold back home.â€

â€œSoap goes bad?â€

â€œIt can.Â  Iâ€™d rather take the misnamed shit that lasts than take something more legit home and find out it went bad.â€

â€œGood point.â€

â€œWeâ€™ll teach you all the tricks.Â  Itâ€™s a good gig, believe me.â€

â€œYeah.Â  Hey, are those fridges?â€

â€œYeah.Â  I wouldnâ€™t get your hopes up.Â  Power was probably out for months to a year before someone got this building back on line.â€

â€œYou think they have ice cream?Â  Or those push-freezes?â€

â€œYou donâ€™t want ice cream, remember?Â  You want-â€

â€œFrozen dairy-like desserts or something.â€

â€œNow you get it.â€

Dot watched as the younger man jogged across the floor to what was almost certainly his imminent demise.Â  He opened the glass door to the fridge display and began picking his way through cardboard boxes.

She could see the green lights appearing in the background of the display, flicking on one by one, apparently at random.

The older man noticed, stopping in his tracks.

â€œJackson!â€ he screamed the word.

The machine rammed through the wall.Â  Six feet tall, six feet wide, with two legs, it slammed past metal racks, past food in cardboard boxes, through the glass doors, through the metal that the doors were attached to, and into Jackson.

Both legs broken.Â  From the way he hit the ground, his arm might have been broken too.

One mechanical leg thrust out, then dragged Jackson back into the hole in the wall.Â  Another reached out and began depositing a thin white fluid on the bloodstain.

Jacksonâ€™s mentor was running and the machine was just starting to clean up the blood when two more belatedly thrust their way out through the walls.Â  They paused where they were, seemed to decide what they were doing, and then used wheels on their underbellies to roll along the floor, the two forelimbs out and ready.

Gaps appeared in the face of each machine as they drew closer.Â  Jacksonâ€™s mentor shouted to friends elsewhere in the building as he rounded a corner in the shelves and stacks.

He made the mistake of grabbing onto a metal strut at the edge of one set of shelves.Â  The face of the strut moved, changing in angle, and jerked upward.Â  A machine had taken a blade and camouflaged it to look like the red-painted metal surface, and it managed to carve deep into Jacksonâ€™s mentorâ€™s hand.Â  The machine that controlled the blade moved.Â  It wore a cardboard box.

Dot made a mental note of that as she remained frozen, watching.

The people were running, gathering together.Â  They narrowly evaded the machines, using corners and their small size to stay clear as the machines from the fridge wall careened down the wide aisles.

It didnâ€™t matter.Â  They were already dead.

She could hear the gasps and shrieks.Â  Here and there, weapons were deployed.Â  Sprays of darts, more blades from innocuous surfaces, wire.

The gasps became more numerous, the sounds strained, and the activity of the scavengers slowed.Â  The ones who realized what was happening didnâ€™t have the words to report it to the others.

Gas.Â  Invisible, odorless.Â  They gasped and used everything they had to try to draw air into their lungs, but the machines were putting something heavier than oxygen on the ground floor of the store.Â  Now they drowned.

Dot had lost family to this very same thing.Â  She had seen how painful it was, and she had known how painful it was to watch someone she cared about die that way.

She took her time picking through the boxes of vitamins, putting them in her bag.Â  It was nice that the gummy vitamins didnâ€™t rattle.Â  She picked up other things as she navigated the shelves, including bandages and some random bottles.

An explosion drew her attention.

Someone in a costume.

Another explosion, followed by two more, and one of the big machines from the fridge wall collapsed.

Apparently alerted by one of the dying, the woman in costume climbed up onto the shelving units, to get to higher ground where there was air.Â  She threw a blue light out of her hand, and it detonated on impact with the next machine.

Back at the fridges, some of the fridges and surrounding wall had already been reconstructed.Â  Two more of the large cube-shaped machines squeezed through the gaps in the wall that were still there, before getting their wheels under them and hurrying in the direction of the woman in costume.

Dot moved closer to the ground to get a look.Â  It was important to know just how far gone this building was.

The entire area behind the fridges was gone.Â  Green flashing lights, wires, computers and metal twisted into shapes that helped it to provide a framework.Â  Machines were working slowly and steadily to refine and develop things.

In the opposite corner of the building, the hero climbed behind a stack of cans.Â  A spray of flechettes punctured the paper with no resistance- there was no tin to the cans, only the labels and the haphazardly perched tops.Â  The machines had already collected everything and then put things back so it looked like it hadnâ€™t been touched.

The heroine fell and hit the floor.Â  She had been darted, punctured across the face and shoulder.

You die too, Dot observed.

Against all odds, though, the heroine had managed to hold her breath.Â  She got to her feet and she ran.

Dot climbed carefully, avoiding suspicious surfaces as she navigated the piles.Â  She kept one eye out for things she could use and one eye on the heroine.

A box cutter, left on the surface by a past employee.Â  Useful.Â  Dot grabbed it.

One of the machines shifted position.Â  Two legs on the ground in front of it, backside resting on the ground.Â  Its face opened wide, and a salvo of missiles fired forth.Â  Ten, twelve, metal canisters with streams of vapor painting the air in their wake as they flew in lazy arcs or even tumbled through the air before getting their bearings.

However haphazard they looked, they didnâ€™t hit anything they werenâ€™t supposed to.Â  They traced courses between stacks of pasta and boxes of cereal, through the struts of metal shelves, and through the two-inch gaps between shelf and the floor below.

The heroine shot at shelves, bringing down the contents in showers that might block the missiles.Â  Some missiles detonated.Â  Others navigated the falling debris, and the heroine shot at those next.

Some missiles didnâ€™t detonate, but they werenâ€™t missiles in actuality.Â  They were tricks.

The heroine backed up, then saw the two new arrivals, two more of the big â€˜soldierâ€™ machines.Â  She ran for the door.

But the machines had had her since she had let them know she existed.

The heroine made it to the door, and then a metal skewer harpooned her hand.

Blow it up.Â  Lose the hand, Dot thought.Â  She realized she was rooting for the heroine despite herself.

The heroine fought, and sheâ€™d had to stop running to fight.Â  More skewers impaled her forearm, then her other hand.

She used her power, she shot at shelves, but she lacked the angle.Â  The machines reeled in, using the wires attached to the skewers, and the heroine was hauled into the air, arms out to either side, legs dangling.

Dot sat, and she waited.Â  She ate more gummy multivitamins and she observed the machines.Â  She watched as the mess was slowly cleaned up, boxes pulled back into position, products lined up, and sections of floor that had been shattered by missiles were fit together like jigsaw pieces.

Here and there, deep in the craters and crevices, the â€˜trickâ€™ missiles had delivered payloads that werenâ€™t explosive.Â  They looked like veins of metal in rock.Â  In weeks and months, they would â€˜hatchâ€™, revealing the machinery that had built itself within.Â  For now, they were paved over.Â  Smaller machines filled in cracks with something white that would harden, with daubs of black for the speckles in the tile.Â  A blade scraped away the excess, and a small nozzle provided a covering of dust to match surrounding floor.

A close eye would notice where the floor was different, but it would have to be close and careful.

The machines werenâ€™t too challenging to destroy.Â  Dotâ€™s groups had sometimes destroyed them.Â  The trick was that they set in roots wherever they went.Â  Each time they reached a new place, they would keep emerging from that place, from walls and floor and rock and tree.Â  It took care and attention to get the machine out of each of those things, and while that care was being taken, machines elsewhere would emerge, march, and make inroads along the flanks.

Green lights here and there went dark, the machines hibernating.Â  Dot deemed herself safe to move.

She stuck to the high ground, while the still-active machines continued their work below.Â  She eased herself closer to the heroine, and paused, observing.Â  Here and there, the woman kicked or struggled, and the machines didnâ€™t respond.Â  Blood streamed down and dripped from her toes to her floor.Â  Each time blood accumulated enough to drip and make a small splash on the floor, a machine zoomed out to spray at it and then wiped it away before returning to its hiding place beneath a shelf.

Dot leaped.Â  She landed on the womanâ€™s shoulder, and the womanâ€™s face twisted, contorting into a wordless scream at the sudden, added weight on her injured arms and hands.

Then the woman looked at Dot, and her expression changed again.Â  Fear, alarm.

Dot was small, only about as large as the womanâ€™s head, and she was colorful.Â  Her clothes had been stolen from dolls and pieced together with diligent care.Â  Her tail with its fur tuft on the end swished with the box-cutter it held..

â€œHelp me.â€

Dot shook her head.

â€œI have people who are counting on me.Â  I have a sick sibling, they need me to bring in the money from this work.â€

â€œI have people too,â€ Dot whispered.Â  She stuck her tongue up to pick her nose, then drew it back into her mouth.Â  â€œSome sick too.â€

The heroine made a small sound, bowing her head.Â  â€œIâ€™ll help you, Iâ€™ll- Iâ€™ll convince people to give you medical care.Â  We can trade.â€

Dot reached out with one hand, and she pushed the tab that extended the blade from the box-cutter.

â€œIâ€™ll do anything,â€ the heroine said.

â€œAnything,â€ the heroine said, seizing on the pause.

â€œPlease.â€

â€œTell me where my king is and Iâ€™ll be fast.Â  Merciful.â€

â€œI donâ€™t- this isnâ€™t about me.Â  Can you- can you let them know the Machine Army is this far north?Â  They shouldnâ€™t be on this side of the Raleigh chasm.â€

Dot paused.

â€œYes,â€ she said.

Then she cut into the womanâ€™s throat, until blood sprayed from the artery.Â  She opened her mouth wide, until the teeth on the upper half of her mouth pointed in the same direction as the teeth on the lower jaw, and bit in deep, locking her mouth in place.Â  She swallowed the blood, gorging herself.

Vitamins, protein, nourishment.Â  She would fill herself here, then visit her brothers and sisters.Â  Then she would set out on her quest.

A distance below them, machines washed away the blood.Â  After the heroine had been kept up and out of the way long enough to ensure her power wouldnâ€™t be a problem, she would be cleaned up too.

Dot felt energized, her focus as sharp as the box-cutter.Â  She knew where their king was.

King Rinke.Â  Nilbog.

âŠ™

She clung to the underside of the train.Â  The ground was a blur beneath her, periodically studded with rocks and branches.

Those of her kind who ventured into the humanâ€™s civilization didnâ€™t tend to return.Â  She knew it was a risk.Â  She knew she had a one percent chance when it came to this.Â  Sheâ€™d said her goodbyes accordingly.

Blackspot would be left in charge.Â  Heâ€™d been unwell lately, and he might be too unwell to lead their group.Â  He was thirteen and that made him old, and after their discussion, her communicating in broken English and gesture and him communicating in chirp, heâ€™d agreed.Â  She suspected heâ€™d made the decision because he hoped she would bring their king back somehow.Â  It was Blackspotâ€™s only chance at being recycled and made into new life.

Lump would be second in command.Â  Lump had been injured a year ago, after running into humans.Â  He barely moved now.Â  When he died, the group would be more free to move, but they wouldnâ€™t leave him behind until then.

Lump was one of the only big ones that were left.

Dot used her tail to fish out a gummy vitamin from inside her tunic where it sat close to her belly.Â  It stuck to her skin and had to be peeled away.Â  She chewed it slowly and carefully.

She was thirsty.Â  She hadnâ€™t anticipated how dehydrated she would get.Â  The chewing got her saliva flowing, though some unfortunately flowed out through the corners of her wide mouth.

There was a hole that smelled like shit, leading into the train interior, but she didnâ€™t want to climb up into there.Â  Shit didnâ€™t bother her, but the smell would hurt her ability to stay undetected.

She was a scout and a spy, a messenger to a king in captivity.

She would endure.Â  She clung to the bolts and bars, arching her back when she saw a branch or rock that might scrape at her, and she chewed.

The train slowed.Â  She shifted her position, ears reorienting to catch more sound.Â  Every detail she could pick up would matter, now.Â  She was in hostile territory.

The train rolled to a stop.Â  Doors hissed as they opened, and the crowd began to make their way out.Â  Dot peered between the wheels and up, to see the refugees and the scavengers, as well as the men and women and boys and girls in uniforms who came and went.

She dropped to the tracks, and she moved to the dark corner, crawling through the dust and grime to help cover up the color of her spots and outfit.

Too many for her to slip across the platform.Â  Would she have an opening?Â  She crept along, looking for vents, for cracks, or anything where she could slip through.

Too new a building, too maintained.Â  This was nothing like the kingdom or the ruins she had known during her five years of existence.

The only time she had seen this many humans was when their kingdom had been invaded.Â  She had been aware as each set of humans boarded at different stops, but for all of them to get off here, for there to be no more tracks?Â  This had to be the end.Â  Their destination and hers.

She trembled with anticipation as the stream of people from the train slowed.

Boots were more serious than shoes.Â  Matching boots were most serious.Â  She associated matching boots with the men with guns that worked with the people in costume.Â  When men with matching boots and people in costume got together, it was often to kill her kind.

She would save her king.

She crept along the underside of the ledge, where the platform jutted toward the train.Â  When the train left, would she be exposed?

She would do anything for her king.

Her weapon was ready.Â  The box cutter.Â  It still smelled like the blood of the heroine.Â  Of Burnish.

Thinking of the blood made her think again about how thirsty she was.

Dot made her way along the car, until she found one of the holes near the shit-hole.Â  This hole didnâ€™t lead up into the car, there was a grate barring her way, catching hair and other gunk, but it was just wide enough for her to squeeze most of the way into.

She waited, listening, until she heard the clatter.

Her role in the community had been a scout, to start with.Â  She had ended up a leader after a while, but she was still a scout at heart.Â  Exploring new places, figuring out ways to deal with traps, with the enemies that lurked out there.

She had dealt with the Machine Army.Â  This little toy wouldnâ€™t stop her.

With clawed toes and the opposable toe on her foot, she clawed some of the hair out of the drain.

Patience.Â  Care.Â  Machines were predictable, once they had revealed their tricks.Â  The challenge was to find the tricks without being discovered or caught.

She watched as the machine passed under her.Â  Dropping from her hiding place, almost noiseless, she landed right behind it.Â  She used all of her strength to tip it over, then wrapped the hair around the wheel and reached up, tying it to a bit of metal at the base of the hole, where a passing rock or branch had made the metal rougher.

Snagged, caught, but in a believable way.

She darted away, as voices commented on the situation, trying to riddle out what had happened.Â  A human dropped down between the platform and the train itself, ducking low to peer between wheels, looking for the little camera drone.

The platforms were mostly empty, and most of the watchful eyes were focused on the little drone and the issue.

She stuck her head up, ears low and close to her body, tail swishing beneath her, and then made a break for a vent.

A human moved, making a run for her.Â  Shoes slid on the smooth floor of the station platform as the human put herself between Dot and the vent.

â€œNot so fatht,â€ the woman said, as Dot skidded on the floor, stopping.

The woman was small, as humans went, and she wore a costume that covered most of her body.Â  Her mask was roughly cone-shaped, but the paper or wire that kept the mask pointy had been dented or damaged at one point, and the nose drooped a bit.Â  Rodent-like, with ears sticking out and back at the side, flat against the side of her head.Â  The eyes behind the eye-holes were large, dark, and moist.Â  If Dot unfocused her eyes a bit, it looked like there was nothing behind the eyeholes.Â  Dark hair draped around in front of the ears and down the back of the womanâ€™s head.Â  As pointy as the mask was, she wore a hood or a hat with a point going the opposite direction.

She wore a jacket, denim, with a threadbare collar, a striped shirt beneath, and a thin chain belt with mousetraps dangling from it.Â  Her socks were striped as well, extending high enough that they just barely met her denim cut-off shorts.

Dot was willing to admit that if she was going to die, at least it was at the hands of someone with a good aesthetic.

In another time, another world, Dot might have stayed.

But she had a king to rescue.Â  A king adored by his people.Â  A truly great man.

As Ratcatcher reached into a pocket, change jingling, Dot saw opportunity.Â  She leaped for the ground, went under the vending machine, and then ran along the wall, darting for the vent.

Big people were often slow.Â  Ratcatcher wasnâ€™t.Â  Fast reflexes.Â  Fast in general.

But Dot was faster.Â  Had the vent not already had a corner peeled away, Dot wouldnâ€™t have been able to make it inside.Â  As it was, she ducked inside, and Ratcatcherâ€™s gloved fingers only managed to seize the ends of the hairs at the end of Dotâ€™s tail.Â  Dot hauled herself free.

Ratcatcher moved her mask aside, fingers going to her mouth, and then whistled.Â  â€œTrouble!â€

But Dot was already in her element.

She ran through dusty vents, navigating the guts of the building.Â  Flashlights periodically shone into the vents, illuminating areas.Â  She avoided most of those beams of lights, going this way and that, until she found another convenient point, where two pieces of metal werenâ€™t flush together.Â  She squeezed through and pulled her bag after her.

It was another minute until she realized two things.

Ratcatcher had friends.

The convenient openings in the vents and leading from vent to the inside of the walls of the station were there because of those friends.

Dot had dealt with rats before, but these rats were the sort that were very ugly and very large.Â  In the right light, they might have been mistaken for very ugly, small dogs.Â  Dot had always liked that story when the King read it from the scary childrenâ€™s book.Â  The children got the dog and the dog turned out to be a Mexican sewer rat.

These rats were that sort, apparently, and they smelled like Ratcatcherâ€™s pocket had.

She drew her box-cutter, extending the blade, and sized up her opponents.

Three rats against her and her boxcutter.

It might have been an even fight, but she had her devotion to her king on her side.

She would rescue her king.

âŠ™

The building that held her king was fitting for the stories.Â  The statue lacked color, but it had the right atmosphere.Â  She was bleeding but she told herself that this was how things were in those stories.Â  The heroine at the foot of the castle of the evil empire, the king in captivity.Â  She hurt from the battles already fought and faced the greatest challenge yet.

Getting inside wasnâ€™t hard, but getting up was.Â  The vents were barred and had cameras, and people were already on guard when she arrived, keeping a close eye on those same vents.

She could only wait.

Patience was essential to a scout.Â  The fact that every inch of her hurt from her fight with the sewer rats made the patience a little different.Â  She had been hurt before, and she had been hurt in a way that made each breath an effort.

Breathe in, breathe out.Â  If she did that once, she was one step closer to being better and being okay.Â  She knew it was a long journey, but surviving was important.

Surviving was especially important now.

He was close.

She would free him, and he would usher in a new age of greatness for her and her people.Â  She might even have a place at his side, where she could be close to him at all times.

She wasnâ€™t even sure what that would be like.Â  She had been ecstatic when she had seen mere glimpses of him, back in the old Kingdom.

Breathe in, hurt, breathe out, hurt again, feel the scratches and the bites when she shifted position.Â  Breathe in, breathe out, double check she wasnâ€™t anywhere she might be found.

She licked at her wounds, and she licked at the dust and grit, so her colors would be bolder.Â  She licked her hands and ran wet hands over her hair, smoothing it.

She had arrived early in the morning, on the train, and now she waited until the sun was high in the sky.Â  Each breath was a step closer to wellness and moving again.

She dug in her small pack for the bandages.Â  They were the small kind, with sticky sides.Â  She had brought the colorful ones with cartoons on them for luck, and now she placed them over her wounds, along with little bits of cotton and fabric to soak up the blood.

It seemed like there were more people who came and went than there were stars in the sky, but her senses might have been playing tricks on her.

The trickle of people slowed.Â  When some made early returns, they smelled like food.Â  Midday meals, then.Â  She waited until everyone was back and working, sluggish from the food in their bellies, and then she made her move.

Up the underside of the stairs to the second floor.Â  Into a crack between a booth and the wall.Â  Up to the third floor, in a similar way.

There was security guarding the way from the fourth floor to the fifth.Â  A commotion gave her a chance to slip through.Â  It helped that she was small and it helped more that she was experienced.

Now she explored.Â  The fifth floor didnâ€™t seem much like a prison.Â  The sixth was closer, with more security, more computers, more monitors.

She heard a voice, and she caught a familiar name.

A dining hall, with lots of tables, and a kitchen off to one side.Â  It smelled like a hundred different foods.

Braindead was a tactical thinker, who could designate a set area in three dimensions, setting out a rectangular prism where he sensed everything in the area.Â  He could cover a small town with his power and have a general awareness of everything that happened in that town, but if he designated a smaller area, he got more clarity, more attention of simultaneous things at once, and he was aware of stats.Â  Non-numerical values for abstract things like physical wellness, martial combat capacity, and run speed, for everyone in the area.Â  Smaller area, more and more accurate stats.

The drawback was that he was a twenty-something guy that spent an awful lot of time sitting in a chair with a diaper on, drooling, mumbling, and feeling acutely uncomfortable.Â  When his power was active, and for a time after, he was unable to act on his knowledge himself, or even to effectively defend himself.Â  He had been on the side of the good guys, once, which was why his power information was such common knowledge.Â  Something had changed or snapped.

I flew just over the rooftops.Â  It wasnâ€™t me flying at a height where I could pull my phone out, because there was a very real chance I could fly into something like a power line or chimney.

Braindeadâ€™s power operated in three dimensions.Â  X, Y, Z.Â  A set area of north, south, east, west, up, and down.Â  If he wanted all of the stats and information, and if he wanted to minimize the other drawbacks of his power, like the recovery time, up and down were often the variable he could sacrifice.Â  He could cover an area three city blocks wide along the west-east axis and three city blocks long along the north-south axis, while only covering six to ten feet of up and down.

Against Braindead alone, flying high and sticking to rooftops was a really safe bet, to stay out of his realm of awareness.

Against Birdbrain, that was a weakness.Â  Birdbrain was a tactical clairvoyant of a complementary stripe to Braindead.Â  Top-down clairvoyant awareness, much like if Kenzie operated solely through tinker eyes-in-the-sky pointed straight down.Â  She also had thinker powers of another sort, worked into the main clairvoyant power, but she wasnâ€™t an ex-hero, and the information wasnâ€™t in files.

She was really good with a gun, highly mobile, and thus she was very good at defending Braindead while he was incapacitated.

If I stuck to rooftops, Birdbrain would detect me quickly.Â  If I went to the ground, Iâ€™d be in Braindeadâ€™s realm.

I flew under things when I could, just to try to throw Birdbrain for a loop.Â  It took me a second to orient myself and find the buildings I was looking for, even when I knew they were part of the downtown strip.

No sign of Snag or Love Lost.Â  They were already inside, I hoped.Â  With luck, I would be able to get the camera online shortly.

I set down on the roof, my forcefield down, and put my bag down in the corner of the roof, against the raised lip.

Fully aware that it was very likely that an eye in the sky was watching my every move, I used my body to block the view of the bagâ€™s contents, and pulled the camera out, placing it against the corner, where the bag would shield it.Â  I got my notebook out, opened it to an empty page, and put it across the corner of the roof, before pulling out the chips and what turned out to be curry in a pita wrap.

Curry in a pita was not a mix Iâ€™d run into before, but I wasnâ€™t going to complain.Â  I put the wrap on my notebook, weighing it down, and the chips by my bag, against the ledge of the roof.

My backpack shielded most of the camera from view, the notebookâ€™s placement shielded any view of it from above.

I had to take it slow.Â  I sat on the roof, leaning against the ledge, opened the bag, and adjusted the plunger.Â  I reached into the bag, and discovered they werenâ€™t chips, but a salted pork rind thing.

Urg.

I ate a few, penned down some general observations of the neighborhood, and then adjusted the plunger slightly downward, as part of the process of reaching down to fish for another mouthful of overly-salted pork things.

It took maybe a minute and a half to two minutes, because of the regular pauses here and there.Â  I heard the â€˜boopâ€™ through my phone, took that as my signal, and pulled my phone out to cancel the call, being sure to keep it at an angle where someone watching from above me couldnâ€™t see the phoneâ€™s face or display.

I was nervous, remaining where I was.Â  Every moment I was here, I was guarding the camera, the camera was presumably filming, and we were getting information.

Every moment I was here, I was being watched.Â  My forcefield was down, because having it up risked it damaging the roof, building, or the camera.Â  The locals were getting time to figure out what to do with me.

We wanted to stir the hornetâ€™s nest, to keep it stirred to exhaust resources and keep them from being particularly effective villains.Â  Those same hornets could sting.

It was maybe five minutes in total before they decided they were uncomfortable with me being where I was.Â  Across the street, a big guy in costume emerged.Â  Blond haired, a metal mask with fur on it, and a combination of metal and what looked like horn or natural armor plates on a brown costume.Â  His gauntlets looked menacing, with fur, metal, and studs.

Shade â€“ Interlude 4a

Itâ€™s his turn tonight.

They ran, they pushed forward.Â  A crush of people.

Smoke billowed, and it smelled like burning rubber. Â For all the chaos, the noises seemed muted, dulled in how the individual elements mixed, the bodies absorbing the sound.Â  Shouts here and there cut through the cries, the noise of people, the sound of something falling down, but people further ahead in the crowd were actively grabbing others and shoving them to the side, dragging them out of the way.

Even with the high ceiling, the haze of smoke made the exit sign above the door hard to see. Â The point of view blurred, blacked out for an instant as the person blinked.

â€œLancaster fire-â€ Â the point of view said, more to himself. Â His voice soon rose to a bellow. Â â€œDonâ€™t- donâ€™t stampede! Â Donâ€™t shove! Â Weâ€™ll get crammed at the exit!â€

The smoke got to him, and he coughed, hard.

He tried to slow, as if he could influence the crowd. Â The force of people behind him pushed him forward, as heavy as he was. Â He was a big guy. Â Big around the middle, more. Â Only a bit taller than average. Â It was enough that he could almost see over the heads of the crowd.

He saw a young girl fall, and very nearly tripped over her. Â To do so might have killed them both. Â He fell to his knees beside her, grabbing at the edge of a sign on the wall to brace himself, one arm around the girl. Â He became a barrier, battered by those behind him. Â Feet scraped at his back, trying to climb over him.

He watched as the people pushed further down. Â He knew what was happening as it happened. Â That the press of bodies was keeping people from being able to get the door open, that by the time people realized there was no way forward, the people behind them would keep them from retreating. Â There would only be the inexorable, forward pressure.

Straining, every movement made harder by people leaning against him or pushing past him, nearly being knocked over to crush the girl in front of him on three occasions, he rose to his feet. Â For what seemed like a minute, it was all he could do to hold his position.

He looked back, and there was only smoke, people pushing toward the exit. Â He looked toward the exit sign, and there was only the press, people crammed together until they were chest-to-back, shoulder-to-shoulder.

He looked around, at the trash cans, at the signs that were built into the wall, frames sticking an inch or two out, locked plexiglass doors protecting the contents from vandalism. Â He looked up, and he saw the windows and the glass ceiling above the corridor that led out of the mall. Â There were high windows that let the light in, and there were latches on those windows.

He reached down, and the young girl shied away.

â€œUp!â€ he said. Â He seized her arm, and as he leaned down, someone bumped into him. Â He nearly fell on her. Â Only his grip on the side of one of the sign-frames kept him from falling.

He drove an elbow back, striking at the person who had pushed him. Â With more energy, desperation, he reached down to seize the girlâ€™s arm, lifted her bodily into the air, and shifted his grip, grabbing her body to lift her.

â€œGrab on and climb!â€ he called out.Â  â€œGet to the window!â€

She tried. Â Sneakers slid against the plexiglass. Â Fingers gripped the ledge, and even with him boosting her, she couldnâ€™t get up. Â She wasnâ€™t even looking at what she was doing, as she turned her face down and away from the thicker smoke.

Further down the hallway, a group of people fell like dominoes.Â  For those who wanted to get away, get to the exit, people who couldnâ€™t necessarily see past the smoke or the people immediately in front of them, it was an opening, a way to get forward.Â  The mob moved forward. Â A woman screamed, a multi-note sound.

Seizing the opportunity, only seeing the gap, people pushed past him, bumped into him.Â  He was holding the girl as he stumbled, and he dropped her.Â  He doubled over, coughing, trying to keep from getting dragged forward.Â  He was a big guy and the movement of the crowd was such that his feet left the ground at points, when people pressed closer.

The girl, too, coughed. Â She looked at him, wide-eyed, until the smoke forced her to close her eyes, and then she ran for the exit, slipping from his reaching fingers, dodging into a gap of bodies, toward the press, where people were barely able to move.Â  People were panicking in places, voices reaching high pitches.

â€œNo!â€ he bellowed at the girl. Â His voice was lost in the chaos.

He looked up at the sign, and he reached, digging fingers in where the sign and the wall were. Â He stepped on someone, tried to climb toward the window, eye on the latch, darting over to look at the smoke behind him, then up to where the smoke was thick near the ceiling.Â  The plexiglass front of the sign was a hinge, so it could be opened, and he dug his finger into that gap for the leverage it could afford.

The climb would have been hard on its own, but he was jostled. Â His hand slipped, and both his fingernail and the tip of his finger tore off as his hand came away from the hinge. Â A thin streak of blood was drawn on the plexiglass.

Someone slid between him and the wall, and he was no longer able to hold himself up. Â He landed on the ground, and people walked over him. Â His efforts to stand were defeated Â by the feet trampling him. Â He couldnâ€™t stop coughing, and his vision distorted from the effort.

Â The view blurred with the tears in his eyes, growing dark as the people closed in above him.

âŠ™

A scene faded, unremembered.Â  Points of light became light.Â  Darkness became shadows in a large, dark room.
