Swinging his feet over to the side of the bed, he looked at his hands, turning them over. Â There was no sign of the dirt, grit.Â  No damage from moving the objects on the five sided table, no cuts on his fingers or blood on the back of his hand.

As he often did, he reached out for his individual powers. Â His own power was at its ordinary strength. Â The scythes of shimmering, flickering light appeared in each of his hands.Â  It felt right.

The emotion power- he reached for it and cast it out over the empty space in the middle of his room. Â He was aware of it like heâ€™d be aware of a patch of shade. Â The effectiveness wasnâ€™t much sharper than creating the shade would be.

When he reached for the tinker power, the ideas that came to mind were paltry, barely much better than how he might manage setting up a snare or the steps for forging a knife.Â  He wasnâ€™t even especially good at those things.

That left the mover power. Â He used it to get to his feet, pushing himself out of bed and using the power rather than his balance to steady himself.

Heâ€™d slept in a t-shirt and boxers, and felt exposed as he canceled out the arrested movement of the mover power, stepped over to the door and shut it.Â  He pulled on a dirty pair of jeans and ran his fingers through his shoulder-length hair until it was reasonable.

His family tended to subscribe to the notion that the kitchen was the center of the home. Â The buildings that had been erected for the settlement were set up in a way that made for large kitchens. Â Wood was burning at a massive brick stove with room for six frying pans on it, and there were two girls Rainâ€™s age handling food there. Â He couldnâ€™t quite remember their names. Â Heather and Lauren, maybe. Â Or was one of them Jean? Â Heâ€™d seen them around, but they didnâ€™t go to the school and theyâ€™d never talked to him.

Rainâ€™s auntie was at the counter, grating potatoes. Â Her daughter, Rainâ€™s cousin Allie, stood talking to one of the men that was sitting at the table, while she took her time drying a dish.

Rain knew only one of the men at the table- an uncle, who had said ten words at most in all the time Rain knew him. Â There was no introduction made for the other two men who sat there.

As good as the food was, as much as the stove was warm and the family close and busy, it wasnâ€™t warm in atmosphere. Â There was no small talk. Â There were some glances from Allie, who was washing and drying, and from the girls at the stove. Â The glances were reserved for when they thought he wasnâ€™t looking.

They werenâ€™t kind looks.

Hash browns, â€˜made properlyâ€™, his Aunt would say, and french toast cut in thick slices from homemade bread. Â The bread that wasnâ€™t being used to make french toast was sitting in a basket on the table, with jam and butter sitting nearby. Â With the production that went into cooking, there was a lot of pressure to eat, to get full. Â For most, it was necessary, with long days of hard work on the farms.

Not that Rain worked on the farms much.

â€œThank you for breakfast,â€ he said.

The girls didnâ€™t respond.

â€œYou gonna have a shower?â€ his aunt asked.

â€œA quick one,â€ he said.

â€œStomp when youâ€™re done,â€ she said, turning the knob at the base of the sinkâ€™s faucet, cutting off the water. Â The plumbing in the house wasnâ€™t great, and the cold water being turned on meant the shower water would scald.

He gathered his dishes.

â€œYou can leave that for the girls.â€

â€œI already got it,â€ he said.

He collected a few more things, aware of the looks from the men sitting around the table, and took them to the side of the sink where the dirty pans and dishes were waiting to be washed.

Allie, standing next to him, pulled a knife out of the drying rack.Â  The metal made a sound as it ran against the side of the rack, singing slightly in the wake of it.Â  Between that, the weapon, the hostility he felt from the two girls at the stove, he shivered slightly.Â  He looked out the window.

Those people I saw in my dream want me dead.

Heâ€™d paused too long, lost in thought, being as tired as he was.Â  He was very aware of the stares, of the long looks from the men at the table, his uncle excepted. Â The girls had paused in their work.

â€œWhat?â€ his aunt asked, her voice sharp. Â She glanced at the girls. Â Her voice was sharper as she asked, â€œWhat, do you need someone to come up and wash you?â€

â€œGross,â€ one of the girls at the stove said.

â€œHey!â€ one of the men barked the word. Â The girl jumped. Â A rebuke without any elaboration.

â€œNo, auntie, I was just thinking,â€ Rain said, feeling his face get hot.

â€œThen save the thinking for school and get going. Â We need the sink free to finish the dishes.â€

He got going.

The shower was hot, even with the cold water cranked all the way around, and he rushed through the process of getting clean. Â The soap, spooned out of a jar with a wooden spatula to his hands, then applied to the critical areas, was a gooey mess derived from animal fat and ash. Â He had no idea what the shampoo was, but it was harsh enough to make his scalp hurt, so he only used it every two or three days.

He had scratches and bruises, only some of them from his time with Victoria and the team. Â He was ginger with them all, checked for the redness of infection, and dabbed them dry instead of toweling more roughly as he finished showering and started getting dry. Â He stomped hard on the floor, three times, as he stepped out of the shower. Â The pipes knocked as the water downstairs was turned on again.

The recluse was planning something for three nights from now. Â He needed to plan, conserve strength. Â It was possible he would be incapacitated, if the others found a way to hijack the rotation or interfere with his days.

His thoughts were occupied with the logistics and conversations heâ€™d need to have as he wrapped a towel around his waist, checked for chin scruff, and then crossed the hall to enter his room. Â Clean clothes, bag, shoes.

He did his best to stay out of sight of the kitchen as he headed downstairs, ducking into the front hall and out the door.

The dirt road cut a zig-zagging line between homes and fields. Â Things had been situated in a way that had been convenient at the time, but the layout didnâ€™t make for good town planning otherwise. Â Other students were walking to school, older siblings watching the younger ones, friends meeting to talk. Â Some parents walked with their children to supervise. Â Other adults were around to supervise. Â The notorious and inevitable Mrs. Sims was bitching at a group of the fifth graders, splitting up groups of friends to make the boys and girls walk on different sides of the road.

A truck came down the road, and the students moved to the muddy sides where the ground was far softer. Â It was Jay, stopping periodically to let friends hop into the back.

Shade â€“ 4.4

I was being watched.

I was being watched at a time when Rain was gone, hiding, when Tattletale was in play.Â  We had enemies, Iâ€™d drawn attention.Â  These things, though, werenâ€™t at the forefront of my attention.Â  It said a lot that they werenâ€™t.

The slash on Mooseâ€™s face lingered in my mindâ€™s eye, when I wasnâ€™t careful about where that eye was turned.

The train was noisy as it rolled along the tracks.Â  With the longer train journeys, I was primed to expect that the urban would give way to the rural or the buildings on either side would stop.Â  It didnâ€™t.Â  Like a car driving down the highway at night, the streetlights reaching into the vehicle interior and then dropping away, the sunâ€™s light did much the same when it reached in at a low angle, extending between buildings to light up the dark train car.

It was just late enough in the morning that most students had made their way to school, but the students with classes in the afternoon block that had stopped in to check in or change were now leaving the schools.Â  They were heading off to work, to do light construction work, for academic clubs, study halls and to join the patrol block, and many were dressed accordingly.Â Â  They looked so young.

The train car was packed, and I was glad Iâ€™d managed to get a seat, even though it was one of the narrow, tiny ones by the door that flipped up to be flush with the wall, when a wheelchair or baby carriage needed the room.

Iâ€™d first noticed the person watching me because her face had a lot of freckles, and out of the corner of my eye, Iâ€™d thought she was someone else.Â  On closer look, though, I could see that her hair was jaw length and straighter, her facial structure was different, and she was wearing the clothes of a student athlete, with bare shoulders and arms, gym shorts, and a towel around her neck.

I might have dismissed her then, but sheâ€™d been looking at me, looking away when I glanced her way.Â  I found myself looking again a few moments later, because one look wasnâ€™t enough to dismiss the unease I felt in response to a freckle-covered face looming in my peripheral vision, peering past the crowd.Â  The same thing happened the second time I looked at her.Â  I caught her staring, and she looked away.

There had been a time that I would have automatically assumed it was positive.Â  I was recognizable, Iâ€™d been a hometown celebrity in a town with a fair number of prominent people, and that had led to me getting recognized by at least one person each time I went out.Â  Iâ€™d reveled in it.

Now?Â  Traitorous instincts made that the second or even the third rank option in a list.Â  The first thought in my head on realizing I was being stared at was to go straight to the hospital room, to people staring at wretched me in a vain effort to try to comprehend what they were looking at.Â  They wondered how I even functioned, how I worked, tried to understand the configuration.Â  When I moved automatically, the movements caught the eye.

Even with the most polite and iron-willed of them, they struggled to find which eye or eyes they should look at to make and maintain eye contact, and in the search for that common, natural thing, they ended up staring at the rest of me.

At the rest of the wretch, the sideshow freak, the monster.

How had Byron put it, at the meeting with Foresight?Â  Tristan was nourished by the hardheaded struggle.Â  Byron was recharged by periods of rest.Â  It gave Tristan a natural advantage in their endless struggle over a single body.

I was closer to Byron in that.Â  I was recharged by attention, by adulation, encouragement, worship.Â  It was a natural progression of the fact that Iâ€™d been built to be a hero, because I could put on a costume and do great things and get that attention and encouragement.

Had I done things in a different way, it could have even been constructive and healthy.Â  But Iâ€™d been a stupid kid.Â  Arrogant.Â  A little worship was good.Â  Iâ€™d worshiped Dean.Â  Heâ€™d worshiped me.Â  On a level, Iâ€™d reached for the wrong things in places, prioritized certain things over others in how I handled the adulation and the public.Â  There were a lot of things I wished Iâ€™d done differently.

That wasnâ€™t even the biggest part of why, much like Byron, I couldnâ€™t go to my most natural ways of finding recharge.Â  Like how mental illness obscured the ability of the person in question to even see the problem at hand, my capacity to recover was distorted and damaged.Â  Tainted.

Tristan had remarked on it too, now that I thought about it.Â  Needing people.Â  He wanted to party, to abandon restraint.Â  I wantedâ€¦ I supposed I wanted not to illogically, automatically, inevitably think of the wretched thing that had occupied that hospital room, anytime someone paid particular attention to me.

I wanted to not feel a deep sadness sinking in when I caught someone staring.

In the places my head went, the wretch loomed in first place, the hero celebrity in second.Â  The third place possibility was that this girl looking at me was something nefarious, and that the young, freckle-faced athlete was an agent of Tattletale or a hire from Cedar Point.Â  Not impossible, but not likely.

Then the fourth place possibility, that she thought I was attractive, not impossible.Â  The fifth place possibility that I had a piece of my breakfast stuck to my cheek or something in my hair.Â  The sixth place possibility, that she was staring off into space and I was somehow always in the wayâ€¦

My thoughts were mired in something so minor, my heart ached indistinctly, and I was just making myself anxious and upset.

I checked my phone.Â  I could focus on the job.Â  The mission at hand.

Shade â€“ Interlude 4b

Rain climbed down from the back of the pickup truck, slinging his bag over his shoulder with the contents rattling. Â Two older guys departed at the same time. Â The truck puttered as Rain walked around to the driverâ€™s side door. Â He handed over some bills. Â The inside of the truck was choked with the smell of cigarettes, and the man at the wheel was partially obscured in the dark and smoke, his features lit by the changing colors of the radio display.

â€œThank you,â€ he said.Â  He didnâ€™t sound like himself.

He only got a grunt in response. Â The driver counted the money before putting it aside.

The two older guys approached the window, one of them with a twenty-four pack of beer that looked badly weathered, as if it had sat out in the rain for a month. Â It was the other that went to the window to pay.

With the settlement being so off the beaten track, the only way to get in and out was to either have a working vehicle or to pay someone to make the drive. Â Rain was pretty sure that his comings and goings were being reported to people higher up the food chain.

He didnâ€™t have alternatives, not unless Erin gave him a ride.

He kept his head down and made the walk along the side of the road. Â Here and there, the packed dirt was loose, not held together by weeds or grass, and his footing slipped. Â It made the walk a trudge.

It was late, and houses were lit by candle and lamps. Â Across the field, a tall bonfire blazed. Â The two guys with the beer were making their way there, climbing over a fence to take the shortest path possible. Â Were Rain to visit, heâ€™d see people like Jay. Â Old enough to mess around and get into trouble, but not yet married. Â There had been a time when heâ€™d wanted to be one of the older boys at those little parties.

Were he to visit, heâ€™d be grudgingly welcomed. Â Heâ€™d be expected to laugh at the jokes, to agree with the things said, to play along. Â He would be expected to take the ribbing and jokes at his expense, and there would be a lot. Â He would be expected to keep to the unspoken contract. Â Adults let those kinds of gatherings happen because the people who attended played along. Â They didnâ€™t complain too much when it came time to do something with or for the sake of the community. Â The tribe. Â The gang.

Rain walked, well aware heâ€™d let the day, afternoon and early evening slip away from him. Â Heâ€™d left the others and caught a train, and heâ€™d been unable to bring himself to come back here. Â â€˜Homeâ€™.

Jittery nervousness had transformed into a dull feeling of dread. Â That dread leeched into and through him like a poison, as if his realization about his high chance of dying had transformed into something that made him feel like he was being eaten alive, being killed by the dread.

He would have thrown up, if he werenâ€™t so tense that he wasnâ€™t sure he could bend over and bring himself to.

He pushed himself forward.Â  Erinâ€™s house was the next one, and there was light in the window.Â  He trudged onward, the earth at the side of the road giving way beneath his feet, as he sank in, pulled himself up and forward, then sank again in a few steps later.

He would have walked in the middle of the road, but Jayâ€™s group was out there at the fire drinking, and Rain didnâ€™t trust them or many of the others to have headlights on and their eyes on the road.

Erin was there, sitting at her window on the second floor.Â  She was keeping an eye out for him, still wearing the shirt with the cross on the front from earlier.Â  The light from her television cast the shadows around her in various shades of green.

She raised a hand in a wave as he drew close enough for the light from the houseâ€™s windows to illuminate him.Â  He raised his own hand.

With the house being at the end of a path, and Erin being on the second floor, her voice was almost inaudible as she asked something.Â  She pointed with him as she asked it, then raised her hand in a barely-visible ok sign.

Was he okay?

Rain stood a very real chance of dying.

He was standing there, not responding, his thoughts tearing through his brain.Â  He had options but none of them were options.Â  If he went to the Wardens for help he would become embroiled in something bigger, because he knew things and heâ€™d be expected to share those things.Â  The Fallen would target him and there was no guarantee the Wardens could keep him safe.Â  There was a chance it would push away Erin and pull him away from the group, as he was taken to safe custody and expected to testify.Â  There was a chance the revelation would mean Victoria pushed him away, or Sveta did, or even Chris or Kenzie.

The person online- no guarantees.

â€œYeah!â€ Erin replied.

He let himself into the house and put his bag by the stairs.Â  Everyone was in the kitchen.Â  His uncle was looking over the paper from earlier in the day.Â  Allie had a crossword and dictionary, and Rainâ€™s aunt was engaged in what seemed like her neverending stream of tidying-up and tending to the property.

â€œSorry Iâ€™m late,â€ Rain said.

Rain did.Â  His uncle was of average height, muscular as many of the farmers were, with graying blond hair that Rainâ€™s aunt cut neatly every few days, and very tan, weather-worn skin.Â  The man could have looked so normal and disarming, with a face that might even have looked friendly, but instead he wore a perpetual glower.Â  He never smiled, and he rarely if ever spoke.

There was no light in his uncle.Â  Had Rain not lived with the man for years, he might have said he was a sociopath, just in how he held himself, the look in his eyes, and how joyless his rote existence seemed.Â  If the Fallen needed a job done and wanted able, loyal bodies, Rainâ€™s uncle would go without question or hesitation.

â€œWhat are you waiting for?â€ Rainâ€™s aunt asked.Â  â€œDonâ€™t keep him waiting.â€

Rain hurried, going back to the bottom stairs where heâ€™d left his bag.Â  He opened the bag as he reversed direction, heading to the kitchen, fishing in the bag for the things he needed.

He had one mechanical arm out as he passed his aunt and cousin.Â  His aunt was unreadable.Â  Not as dark as his uncle was- his aunt gave the impression the light had been almost entirely extinguished, but the woman could smile, for the rarest of occasions.Â  She had things she cared about and prioritized.Â  Dim or reduced to dark embers, but not gone.

He pressed the arm to his shoulder blade, and felt the connection flare, burning through his nerves to his brain.Â  A small, tiny window opened in his consciousness, with his awareness of the arm and its position.Â  He was aware of the air against the current that ran along the outside â€˜skinâ€™ of the arm and hand.

He used the extra arm to help hold the bag while he got the other arm out, slapping it back against the blade of his other shoulder.

His uncle waited by the wooden fence, the perimeter made up of only three broad wooden slats punctuated by the stout posts.

Standing there, illuminated only by the porchlight, his uncle gave no impression there had ever been a light there at all.

Rain had two more arms to connect, but they were smaller, attached at the elbow, only reaching as far as his wrist.Â  They were older and heâ€™d tuned them back up to working order with the intention of leaving one for Kenzie to study.Â  Heâ€™d forgotten, in his haste to leave.

He approached his uncle.Â  When he got within three or so paces, his uncle took a step toward him.Â  No prelude, no intent apparent in his action.Â  With a second long stride, the man reached out to shove Rainâ€™s shoulder hard, pushing him toward the fence.

Rain cast out the emotion power around them, and felt the feedback buzz, the faint response that let him know the power was working.

That done, he reached up.Â  His normal hand grabbed his uncleâ€™s wrist.Â  A mechanical hand grabbed his uncleâ€™s elbow, fingers digging in there, in an attempt to force it to bend.Â  The smallest hand grabbed for two fingers, pulling them backward.

His uncle pulled his hand up and away, and then kicked Rain in the thigh.

Rain fell, his mechanical hands were too slow to let go, and he could see as the two right arms came apart in pieces, wires stretching between wrist and forearm, forearm and elbow, before snapping.Â  The individual parts fell to the shadows and grass.

His uncle kicked him while he was down, boot to ribs.

Rain reached for the pieces, picking them up with two left hands.Â  The forearm, broken at the front, was almost like a broken bottle.Â  He scrambled back, two broken pieces of his arms held in his real hand and his one remaining, full-size mechanical arm.

He dismissed the emotion effect, re-cast it out, just to ensure it was over his uncle.Â  Not that it seemed to do much.Â  Heâ€™d tried letting it sit on people and some of the farm animals before.Â  It didnâ€™t work.Â  He could only hope there was some nuance he could use.

Fuck, his ribs and leg hurt where heâ€™d been kicked.

His uncle walked away, his back to Rain.Â  He approached the fence, then reached over it.Â  Allie wasnâ€™t far away.Â  Sheâ€™d gone through the gate and was leaning against the outside of the fence, watching.

A shovel.Â  Rainâ€™s uncle had picked up the shovel that had been leaning against the fence, almost as long as Rain was tall, with a spade-shaped head.Â  There was an implicit â€˜if youâ€™re going to wield a weapon, so am Iâ€™ to the act.

â€œDonâ€™t kill him,â€ Rainâ€™s aunt said, from the stairs to the kitchen.

â€œI donâ€™t want to have to explain it to the leadership,â€ she said.

Rainâ€™s uncle reversed his grip on the shovel, holding it near the spade-end with both hands.

Rain backed away a little as his uncle approached.

The first swing of the shovel was preliminary, measuring distance.Â  Swung like a baseball bat, it made the â€˜whooshâ€™ sound as it sliced through the air.Â  If Rain hadnâ€™t leaned back, it might have connected with his nose.

Rain lunged forward.Â  He had smaller weapons.

His uncle didnâ€™t swing the shovel back the other way.Â  Instead, moving his hand up to grip it at the middle, he swung it so the upper end caught Rainâ€™s mechanical arm, the lower end caught his wrist.

The mechanical arm broke with the impact, the shattered forearm dropping from its grip.

Rain felt the pain of the impact against his wrist as something that extended along his entire forearm, through his hand, tingling in his fingers.

He knew how to throw a punch, and with his uncle holding nothing back, he had no reason to do so either.Â  He closed the distance, his chest connecting with his uncleâ€™s as he punched low, aiming for the stomach, just beneath the ribs.Â  Repeated blows, strikes with fist sharp against muscle and fat.

Fingers tangled in his hair, gripped tighter until Rainâ€™s scalp hurt.Â  He was pulled away, then without the hand letting go, he was flung into the fence, cheekbone and shoulder crashing into the broad plank closer to the top.

He was pulled away, not allowed to get his balance, and then thrust toward the fence again.

He used his mover power to arrest the push, to make himself stop.Â  He drove his elbow into his uncleâ€™s arm, where only the connection pad and the shattered remnants of the arm remained, raking the damaged metal and wire against flesh.

His uncle pulled away, and Rain was there, suspended for another second.

Rain couldnâ€™t cancel out his mover power before his uncle got his footing and came back at him, driving a knee into his middle.Â  He crashed into the fence and landed hard.

He hauled himself to his feet, one hand on the fence, and his uncle kicked him before he was entirely there.Â  A kick at the armpit, so Rainâ€™s hand couldnâ€™t support him any longer.Â  His mover power wasnâ€™t available to stop him from falling, and- and it wouldnâ€™t have mattered in the slightest if it were.

The pain radiated through him, now.Â  His uncle stood tall, one hand at his arm, which was bleeding, and paced.Â  The feedback Rain got wasnâ€™t accurate enough to let him know where his uncle was, and it was hard to find a position where he could look up and over.

He grabbed the fence and heaved himself to his feet.

His uncle looked at his aunt, and Rain took that as an opportunity to sprint full-bore for the man.Â  He leaped, heedless of personal risk, of the fall that might follow, and kicked sideways with all of his force.

He connected, shin to side.Â  He saw the pain on his uncleâ€™s face.Â  Then he used his power to suspend himself, before he could tumble hard to the ground.

It suspended him for too long.Â  There was no canceling it, and however long it lasted, a second and a half, two seconds, maybe even approaching three seconds, it was enough time for his uncle to turn his way and kick him, hard.

Rain dropped, in too much pain to calculate how he broke free of the powerâ€™s hold, and landed in the grass and dirt.

He was kicked several times while he was down.Â  Back, buttock, leg.Â  He wasnâ€™t sure if heâ€™d been kicked sharply in the side or if it was only the way heâ€™d recoiled and made an existing wound pull that made it feel like it.

His mechanical hands broke at the slightest excuse, his emotion power didnâ€™t do anything he could identify, and his mover power made him a sitting duck in any real combat situation.

The kicking had stopped.Â  Rain lay there, his breaths coming out as wheezes.Â  His thoughts were so mired in sick hopelessness that he could barely think straight.

A hand was extended.Â  It seized Rain by the upper arm, firm, and heaved him to his feet.

It occurred to Rain, too late, that his uncle wasnâ€™t the kind of person to offer a helping hand.

Still firmly holding Rainâ€™s upper arm, with Rain bent over, his uncle struck him across the face.Â  It was only the fierce grip on Rainâ€™s arm that kept him from being knocked to the ground yet again.

Again, Rain was struck across the face.Â  His head sagged.

The next hit caught him backhanded, across the ear.Â  It was impossibly loud, painful, and it made his thoughts dissolve into sparks.Â  His ear rang like a siren in the wake of the hit.

Rain, almost insensate, punched in the general direction of his uncleâ€™s stomach, turned his face toward the ground so it would be away of any further blows, and kept punching blind until his uncle let him go.

Rain stumbled back, snorted, coughed, and tried to straighten, before giving up on the latter.Â  He put his hand on his knee to steady himself.

His uncle approached, and Rain backed up.Â  His uncleâ€™s turn to return the favor, now.Â  Swats, a knee, a punch, a shove.Â  Even the lighter contact was painful, because Rain hurt, and each light contact forced him to move one way or the other while existing bruises and injuries punished those movements.

â€œOkay,â€ Rain managed, huffing out the word.Â  â€œStop.â€

His uncle didnâ€™t stop, pushing out with both hands to shove Rain back into the wooden fence.

With an edge of desperation, Rain pulled out the silver blades.Â  It didnâ€™t make his uncle hesitate.

He threw the first blade, and the pain at his armpit altered the trajectory, meant he didnâ€™t finish the swing.Â  The silver scythe passed through his uncleâ€™s head, the two remaining pieces carrying forward, sailing out to strike the side of the house.

A silver line encircling his head, Rainâ€™s uncle stood there, drawing in a deep breath.

â€œOkay,â€ Rain said.Â  He hunched over, hands on his knees, coughed, then snorted.Â  â€œDonâ€™t sneeze or do anything.Â  Thatâ€™s all.Â  Thank you.â€

His uncle remained where he was, glowering, eye sockets only barely illuminated by the silver light from the mark.

The mark would fade soon.Â  Ten, twelve seconds.Â  Rain watched and waited, nervous of the possibility of disaster.

The spell was broken as his alarm clock buzzed.Â  He always set it for the evening, not the morning, because there was a timeframe.

Cradle.

His dreams are strange.

A hand slamming down on the table, a paper beneath it.Â  A mouth opening.Â  A man that might have been Cradleâ€™s father spoke, but it wasnâ€™t words that came out.Â  It was the frantic cries of the crowd, the screams, the shouted jumble.

The paper crumpled slightly as the hand on it closed into more of a fist.

In the background, a very prim and proper woman stood with her back to Cradle.

The parents, Rain interpreted.Â  Disappointment and anger.Â  I can understand that.

The scene changed.Â  A balding man in a suit, sitting across from a desk.Â  The bulletin board behind him had childâ€™s artwork on it.

His expression was plaintive, worried.Â  The words from that somber older manâ€™s face were the scream of someone that had been burned, stopping as lips closed together, starting as they parted.Â  His hand moved more papers, sorting through the pile in front of him.

Cradleâ€™s point of view moved, shaking left and right as he shook his head.

The balding older manâ€™s expression changed from worry to something stronger.Â  Upset.Â  Deep concern.

The principal, Rain interpreted.Â  Heâ€™d seen variations on this.Â  It was usually like this, or else smoke, rubble, or broken glass poured from peopleâ€™s mouths instead of words.Â  Cradle wasnâ€™t doing so well?

He could understand that too.

Itâ€™s even of a similar vein.Â  Unrealized potential, as far as I can understand it.Â  Report cards, teachers, father figures, they want something from him and he doesnâ€™t deliver.Â  He doesnâ€™t hand it over.

Then the long hallway.Â  The trudge.Â  Cradleâ€™s hand was visible as he reached up to fix his glasses, as he reached out to the window.Â  In the distance, far away, the sounds of disaster could be heard.Â  The stampede, the fire.

School again?Â  A lonely hallway?Â  Isolation?Â  I used to call him the recluse.

Cradle took off his glasses, and all was a blur.Â  When he put them back on, he was facing teenaged peers.

Their faces moved as if they were shouting, expressions twisting.Â  The only sound to come out was that of the stampede.Â  Feet tromping, people shouting with words blending into one another.Â  Teeth came together as a word was finished, and the sound was of a bone breaking.Â  One of the teenagers pushed Cradle down.Â  His glasses were set ajar by the fall.

This time, as he fixed the glasses, he was in the shopping center, standing.

Things moved as if in slow motion.Â  Inevitable.

What does Cradle feel when heâ€™s here?Â  Dread?

Cradleâ€™s head turned, everything moving as if it was underwater, as he looked at a group of men and women with tattoos.Â  They were loud, too loud, as they gathered together, talking among themselves.

He looked the other way.Â  He saw other faces.Â  Faces that would be in the crowd shortly.Â  A couple that were about thirty years old.Â  Then an older man and woman.

The old couple get trampled early on, Rain thought.

Eyes roved slow-motion in the other direction.Â  In a store with colorful graphic images in frames, and other things in glass cases, a big guy with long hair, a nose ring and an impressive beard was talking to an older man, while tapping one of the framed cartoon images.Â  No sound came out of his mouth as his lips moved.

Images like this would be the best Rain would get at seeing Snagâ€™s face uncovered.

There were others.Â  The twelve year old girl with her friends, that Snag would fail to help.Â  She would die in the crush, after slipping from Snagâ€™s grip.

A lot of the children and elderly in the mall would be counted among the dead.

One of the three girls said her goodbye to her friends.Â  The movement was slow motion as she ran across the plaza of the mall.

She was smiling as she approached the woman who waited for her.Â  The smile fell from her face, she slowed, then hung her head.

The woman showed the girl her watch, tapped it, her words were stern and entirely unheard.Â  There was only silence in this slow motion prelude to the event.

The woman with wavy red hair, a sweater that failed to hide her impressive chest, and an ankle-length skirt.Â  Heads turned to watch her berate the child.Â  The child looked nervously back at her friends.

Love Lost.

Things accelerated, as the scene rushed forward.Â  Everyone to their positions.

Three explosions in quick succession, loud after the silence, the blasts tearing across the plaza the opening of one of the exits.Â  Blue flame.

Then the movement, everyone trying to get away.Â  The layout of the shopping center allowed only one good escape route, and everyone rushed for it.

Another acceleration, skipping ahead in time.Â  The sound of the stampede, the crowd, all of the noises that had been made or hinted at earlier, now came to the forefront, crashing into the present moment.Â  Cradle was close to the front of the crowd.Â  He was shoved, he tried to catch his balance, and he fell.Â  His glasses came away from his face, they were stepped on.

Twice, he reached for the glasses, and his hands were stepped on.Â  There was a desperation in it, more of a struggle to get them than there was even an attempt to stand.Â  The scene was blurred but his hands were as clear as anything.

Close by, a woman screamed, and the sound was prolonged, multi-part.

He reached up, hand extended.

The church service concluded.Â  The speakers rotated on the regular, and todayâ€™s was Mrs. May.Â  She was a respected figure in the community, but she wasnâ€™t respectable.Â  She was a harpy of a person, with a shrill voice and a grating laugh she was inclined to use at the slightest provocation, and most people either loved her and her rhetoric, or they despised her.Â  She performed a lot of sermons, usually with plenty of warning to others and often with women in attendance.Â  Much of what she said appealed to that crowd.

Different preachers to appeal to different crowds, with diehard adherents attending every sermon.Â  It didnâ€™t matter that the ideas contradicted, that the sermon the nervous Reverend Patman gave to a small congregation of Mrs. Simsâ€™ type was the polite kind of message that could be heard elsewhere, while the inappropriately dressed Mrs. May preached how wives had the duty of keeping their husbandsâ€™ balls drained, prostates massaged, and stomachs full.

Rain could trace his family connection to most of those present.

He looked.

Heâ€™d only seen her leg and foot, and sheâ€™d jumped into his head, tactile, audible, present, impossible to ignore.

It was worse.

â€œWhy would you leave, when we havenâ€™t talked?â€ she asked.Â  â€œYouâ€™ve been standing there, talking to yourself.â€

â€œSorry, mama,â€ he said.

â€œYes, mama,â€ he said.

â€œEvery time you think of me or mention me, I will be there.Â  I will know where you are and see what you are doing.Â  I will take stock and I will make my judgments.Â  You will think of me, while saying your prayers on waking and on retiring, kneeling by your bed.Â  Before each meal.â€

Shadow â€“ 5.1

Experience told me that after waking up from a bad dream, it was better for me to move.Â  The emotional and mental impact of being tired for the rest of the day was far lower than if I remained in bed and stewed.Â  Either way, I rarely fell back into sleep.

It was one of the few things that had been easier at the hospital.Â  Sleep had been regular, reliable.Â  There hadnâ€™t been any stretches where Iâ€™d have nightmares or insomnia for three nights in a row and the littlest things would be a grind by the third day.Â  The drugs had been part of my diet, to ensure I fell asleep and woke up at certain times.Â  They didnâ€™t do much about the nightmares, but even waking up hadnâ€™t ended the nightmare back then.

I was perpetually tempted to get something to help, but the degree to which I was tempted was a warning bell in the back of my mind.

Sleep, eating, having a space to retreat to, physical affection, attention, socializing, breathing.Â  It was always the basic, animal things that came apart in the wake of stress and crisis.Â  Things broke down, got twisted, or they were reminders.

I woke up and I pulled on a pair of jeans.Â  Red-dyed raw denim, washed with something dark that made the creases and seams very apparent.Â  They were a little looser fitting than my going-out jeans, and Iâ€™d settled into wearing them when I was at home and my dad was around, or now, when Crystal was around.Â  It felt less like I was a slob if I was wearing them at home, especially if anyone dropped in.

Dean had tried on red jeans once, while I was shopping with him.Â  His uncharacteristically self-conscious reaction had had me in stitches.Â  If I hadnâ€™t been able to fly, I would have been on the floor laughing.Â  It was a good memory and a large part of why the jeans were a security-blanket level thing for me.

The memory had a nice second part, when Dean had mentioned that even the brief wearing of the jeans had turned his legs and underwear red.Â  His best friends and I had been there as heâ€™d recounted how concerned heâ€™d been before realizing, and how the redness on his underwear had been worse where it pressed against the jeans, especially at the front.Â  Heâ€™d described it as a clown-nose smudge on the front and his friends had been nearly falling out of their seats.

Even now, it put a smile on my face.

There were other memories too.Â  Some from the same trip, others from other dates.Â  Heâ€™d tried on a lot of jeans and to this day I could remember a pair where he had looked perfect: in profile, in the narrow waist and hips, the broad shoulders, the pert butt.Â  Heâ€™d lifted up his shirt so I could see the fit, and Iâ€™d seen the thin trail of body hair leading up to his navel, his flat stomach, and the bones of his hips just above the jeans.Â  Already warmed up by my laughing fit earlier, Iâ€™d worked myself up into a tizzy, the best words for it, and Iâ€™d maintained the tizzyness until twenty minutes later when we were cutting through the parking lot to the bus stop.Â  Iâ€™d pulled him aside for a make out session.

I missed him so much it hurt, but the memories were happy ones and they were a good buffer against the bad nightâ€™s sleep.Â  I kept my t-shirt and underwear on from yesterday and I went without a bra, pulling on a white sweater with too-long sleeves and a wide collar that left my shoulders bare.

The fit was snuggly and enveloping, as if the sweater itself was giving me a hug; kind of what I was shooting for when a not-insignificant part of me felt like I was five years old again, scared and wanting to crawl into bed with my mom and dad.

Set on putting the nightmare and the associated feelings behind me, I got some socks, underwear, sports bra, and a camisole top, stowing them in my bag where I already had my wallet.Â  I pulled on some sneakers, sans socks, and headed to the balcony door.Â  I eyed the clock in the kitchen as I passed it.Â  Fifteen minutes to five.

I flew toward Cedar Point.
